notes.title: The Core Concept
points: Every composite number can be expressed (factorised) as a product of primes.
This factorisation is unique, apart from the order in which the prime factors occur.
Example: $30 = 2 \times 3 \times 5$. No matter the order, these are the only prime factors.

notes.title: Applications of the Theorem
points: Used to find the HCF and LCM of positive integers.
HCF: Product of the smallest power of each common prime factor.
LCM: Product of the greatest power of each prime factor involved.

formulas.title: HCF and LCM Relationship
formulas.formula: HCF(a, b) \times LCM(a, b) = a \times b
formulas.explanation: The product of two positive integers is always equal to the product of their HCF and LCM.

realworld.title: Cybersecurity
realworld.description: RSA encryption, which secures your online bank transactions, relies on the difficulty of factorizing extremely large composite numbers into their prime components.

notes.title: Defining Irrationals
points: A number is irrational if it cannot be written in the form $p/q$, where $p$ and $q$ are integers and $q \neq 0$.
If $p$ is a prime number and $p$ divides $a^2$, then $p$ divides $a$ (where $a$ is a positive integer).
Common examples include $\sqrt{2}, \sqrt{3}, \sqrt{5},$ and $\pi$.

notes.title: Proof by Contradiction
points: To prove $\sqrt{2}$ is irrational, we first assume it is rational ($p/q$).
We then show this assumption leads to a logical inconsistency (contradiction).

formulas.title: Theorem of Divisibility
formulas.formula: p | a^2 \implies p | a
formulas.explanation: If a prime number $p$ divides the square of an integer $a$, then it must also divide $a$ itself.

realworld.title: Architecture and Design
realworld.description: The Golden Ratio (approximately 1.618...) is an irrational number used by architects and artists to create aesthetically pleasing proportions in buildings and paintings.

topics.name: Rational Numbers and their Decimal Expansions

notes.title: Terminating Decimals
points: A rational number $p/q$ has a terminating decimal expansion if the prime factorisation of $q$ is of the form $2^n 5^m$.
Here, $n$ and $m$ are non-negative integers.

notes.title: Non-Terminating Repeating Decimals
points: If the prime factorisation of $q$ contains factors other than 2 or 5, the decimal expansion is non-terminating repeating (recurring).

formulas.title: Condition for Terminating Decimals
formulas.formula: q = 2^n \times 5^m
formulas.explanation: A fraction terminates only if its denominator's prime factors are exclusively 2s, 5s, or both.

realworld.title: Digital Computing
realworld.description: Computers use binary (base 2). Because some decimal fractions don't have a terminating expansion in binary, small rounding errors can occur in high-precision calculations.

topics.name: Geometrical Meaning of the Zeroes of a Polynomial

notes.title: Understanding Zeroes Graphically
points: A zero of a polynomial p(x) is the x-coordinate of the point where the graph of y = p(x) intersects the x-axis.
For a linear polynomial ax + b, the graph is a straight line that intersects the x-axis at exactly one point: (-b/a, 0).
A quadratic polynomial can intersect the x-axis at most at two points, meaning it can have at most two zeroes.
A cubic polynomial can have at most three zeroes, as its graph can intersect the x-axis at most three times.

notes.title: Graphical Representation
points: The graph of a quadratic polynomial ax² + bx + c is a parabola.
If a > 0, the parabola opens upwards; if a < 0, it opens downwards.
The number of times the graph touches or crosses the x-axis gives the number of real zeroes of the polynomial.

formulas.title: Nature of Roots
formulas.formula: For ax² + bx + c = 0, discriminant D = b² - 4ac
formulas.explanation:
If D > 0: Two distinct real roots (graph intersects x-axis at two points)
If D = 0: One real root (graph touches x-axis at one point)
If D < 0: No real roots (graph doesn't intersect x-axis)

realworld.title: Projectile Motion
realworld.description: The path of a projectile under gravity follows a parabolic curve, which can be modeled by a quadratic polynomial. The zeroes represent the points where the projectile is launched and where it lands.

topics.name: Relationship between Zeroes and Coefficients of a Polynomial

notes.title: Quadratic Polynomials
points: For a quadratic polynomial p(x) = ax² + bx + c with zeroes α and β:
Sum of zeroes: α + β = -b/a
Product of zeroes: αβ = c/a

notes.title: Cubic Polynomials
points: For a cubic polynomial p(x) = ax³ + bx² + cx + d with zeroes α, β, and γ:
Sum of zeroes: α + β + γ = -b/a
Sum of product of zeroes two at a time: αβ + βγ + γα = c/a
Product of zeroes: αβγ = -d/a

formulas.title: Forming Quadratic Polynomial
formulas.formula: x² - (sum of zeroes)x + (product of zeroes) = 0
formulas.explanation: A quadratic polynomial can be formed using the sum and product of its zeroes.

formulas.title: Cubic Polynomial Formula
formulas.formula: x³ - (α+β+γ)x² + (αβ+βγ+γα)x - αβγ = 0
formulas.explanation: The general form of a cubic polynomial in terms of its zeroes.

realworld.title: Engineering Design
realworld.description: In civil engineering, these relationships help in designing curved structures like arches and bridges where the zeroes represent critical points of stress and load distribution.

notes.title: The Division Algorithm
points: For any two polynomials p(x) and g(x) where g(x) ≠ 0, there exist unique polynomials q(x) and r(x) such that: p(x) = g(x) × q(x) + r(x)
Here, r(x) = 0 or degree of r(x) < degree of g(x)
q(x) is called the quotient and r(x) is called the remainder.

notes.title: Steps for Polynomial Division
points: 1. Arrange the terms of both polynomials in decreasing order of their degrees
2. Divide the highest degree term of the dividend by the highest degree term of the divisor to get the first term of the quotient
3. Multiply the entire divisor by this term and subtract from the dividend
4. Bring down the next term and repeat the process until the degree of the remainder is less than the degree of the divisor

formulas.title: Remainder Theorem
formulas.formula: If a polynomial p(x) is divided by (x - a), the remainder is p(a)
formulas.explanation: This provides a quick way to find the remainder without performing the complete division.

formulas.title: Factor Theorem
formulas.formula: (x - a) is a factor of p(x) if and only if p(a) = 0
formulas.explanation: This helps in factorizing polynomials and finding their zeroes.

realworld.title: Signal Processing
realworld.description: In digital communications, polynomial division is used in error-detecting codes like CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check) to ensure data integrity during transmission.

realworld.title: Computer Graphics
realworld.description: Polynomial division is used in computer-aided design (CAD) software to create smooth curves and surfaces by manipulating polynomial equations.

Mathematics.chapterName: Pair of Linear Equations in Two Variables
Mathematics.title: Chapter 3: Linear Equations

notes.title: Understanding the Basics
points: A pair of linear equations in two variables can be represented as:
a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0
a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0
The solution is the point (x, y) that satisfies both equations simultaneously.
The graph of each equation is a straight line.

notes.title: Types of Solutions
points: If the lines intersect at a point: Unique solution (Consistent system)
If the lines are parallel: No solution (Inconsistent system)
If the lines coincide: Infinitely many solutions (Dependent/Consistent system)

formulas.title: Condition for Consistency
formulas.formula: For a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0 and a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0:
formulas.explanation:
If a₁/a₂ ≠ b₁/b₂: Unique solution
If a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ = c₁/c₂: Infinitely many solutions
If a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ ≠ c₁/c₂: No solution

realworld.title: Business Applications
realworld.description: Used to determine the point at which total cost equals total revenue, helping businesses determine their break-even point and profit zones.

notes.title: Step-by-Step Process
points: 1. Solve one equation for one variable in terms of the other
2. Substitute this expression into the other equation
3. Solve the resulting equation in one variable
4. Substitute the found value back to get the value of the other variable

notes.title: When to Use
points: Ideal when one equation can be easily solved for one variable
Particularly useful when coefficients of one variable are 1 or -1
Best for equations where one variable has a coefficient of 1

formulas.title: Example
formulas.explanation: This shows the step-by-step solution using substitution method

realworld.title: Economics
realworld.description: Used to find the equilibrium price and quantity where supply equals demand in market analysis.

notes.title: Step-by-Step Process
points: 1. Make the coefficients of one variable the same (or additive inverses) in both equations
2. Add or subtract the equations to eliminate one variable
3. Solve the resulting equation for the remaining variable
4. Substitute back to find the other variable

notes.title: When to Use
points: Ideal when coefficients of one variable are the same or additive inverses
Useful when both equations are in standard form (ax + by = c)
Particularly effective for larger coefficients

formulas.title: Example
formulas.formula:
For 2x + 3y = 8 and 3x + 2y = 7:
1. Multiply first by 3: 6x + 9y = 24
2. Multiply second by 2: 6x + 4y = 14
3. Subtract: 5y = 10 ⇒ y = 2
4. x = 1
formulas.explanation: Demonstrates elimination by making coefficients of x equal

realworld.title: Chemistry
realworld.description: Used to determine the quantities of different solutions needed to achieve a desired concentration in chemical mixtures.

notes.title: The Formula
points: For equations: a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0 and a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0
x = (b₁c₂ - b₂c₁)/(a₁b₂ - a₂b₁)
y = (c₁a₂ - c₂a₁)/(a₁b₂ - a₂b₁)

notes.title: When to Use
points: Most efficient for solving equations with fractional coefficients
Provides direct solution without needing to eliminate variables step-by-step
Particularly useful when the equations are in standard form

formulas.title: Cross-Multiplication Formula
formulas.formula: x/(b₁c₂ - b₂c₁) = y/(c₁a₂ - c₂a₁) = 1/(a₁b₂ - a₂b₁)
formulas.explanation: This formula gives the solution directly using the coefficients of the equations

notes.title: Understanding Quadratic Equations
points: A quadratic equation in variable x is of the form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a, b, c are real numbers and a ≠ 0.
The highest power of the variable is 2, which gives it the name 'quadratic' (from 'quadratus' meaning square).
Examples: x² - 5x + 6 = 0, 2x² + 3x - 2 = 0

notes.title: Factorisation Method
points: Express the quadratic equation in standard form (ax² + bx + c = 0)
Factorize the quadratic expression
Set each factor equal to zero and solve for x
The solutions are called roots or zeroes of the equation

formulas.title: Factorisation Formula
formulas.formula:
For x² + (a+b)x + ab = 0,
Factors are (x + a)(x + b) = 0
formulas.explanation: Find two numbers that add up to 'b' and multiply to 'c' in x² + bx + c = 0

realworld.title: Projectile Motion
realworld.description: The height of a projectile over time follows a quadratic equation, where the roots represent the times when the projectile is at ground level.

notes.title: Method Overview
points: 1. Ensure the coefficient of x² is 1 (divide by 'a' if needed)
2. Move the constant term to the other side
3. Add the square of half the coefficient of x to both sides
4. Write the left side as a perfect square
5. Take the square root of both sides and solve for x

notes.title: Deriving the Quadratic Formula
points: The quadratic formula is derived by completing the square for the general quadratic equation ax² + bx + c = 0
This method shows why the discriminant (b² - 4ac) determines the nature of roots

formulas.title: Completing the Square Formula
formulas.formula:
For x² + bx + c = 0:
(x + b/2)² = (b/2)² - c
formulas.explanation: This creates a perfect square trinomial on the left side

formulas.title: Quadratic Formula
formulas.explanation: The solution to any quadratic equation in the form ax² + bx + c = 0

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: The shape of arches and suspension bridges can be modeled by quadratic equations, where completing the square helps in determining key structural points.

notes.title: Discriminant Analysis
points: The discriminant (D) of a quadratic equation ax² + bx + c = 0 is given by D = b² - 4ac
D > 0: Two distinct real roots (graph intersects x-axis at two points)
D = 0: One real root (graph touches x-axis at one point)
D < 0: No real roots (graph doesn't intersect x-axis)

notes.title: Sum and Product of Roots
points: For ax² + bx + c = 0 with roots α and β:
Sum of roots: α + β = -b/a
Product of roots: αβ = c/a
This relationship helps form quadratic equations when roots are known

formulas.title: Nature of Roots
formulas.formula: D = b² - 4ac
formulas.explanation: Determines the nature of the roots without finding the roots explicitly

formulas.title: Quadratic in Terms of Roots
formulas.formula: x² - (sum of roots)x + (product of roots) = 0
formulas.explanation: Forming a quadratic equation when sum and product of roots are known

notes.title: Understanding AP
points: An Arithmetic Progression (AP) is a sequence of numbers where the difference between consecutive terms is constant.
The constant difference is called the 'common difference' (denoted by 'd').
First term is usually denoted by 'a' or 'a₁'.
General form: a, a + d, a + 2d, a + 3d, ...

notes.title: Key Characteristics
points: If d > 0: AP is strictly increasing
If d < 0: AP is strictly decreasing
If d = 0: All terms are equal (constant sequence)
The difference between any two terms is an integral multiple of the common difference

formulas.title: nth Term Formula
formulas.formula: aₙ = a + (n - 1)d
formulas.explanation: To find any term in the AP, where n is the term number

realworld.title: Financial Planning
realworld.description: Fixed deposits and recurring deposits in banks often follow an AP, where each installment increases by a fixed amount over the previous one.

notes.title: Derivation and Application
points: The formula aₙ = a + (n - 1)d is derived by observing the pattern in the sequence
Can be used to find any term when first term and common difference are known
Also used to check if a given number is a term of a given AP
If three numbers are in AP, the middle one is called the arithmetic mean of the other two

notes.title: Properties of AP
points: If a constant is added to each term of an AP, the resulting sequence is also an AP
If each term of an AP is multiplied by a constant, the resulting sequence is also an AP
The sum of terms equidistant from the beginning and end is constant

formulas.title: Arithmetic Mean
formulas.formula: For two numbers a and b, AM = (a + b)/2
formulas.explanation: The middle term between two numbers in an AP

formulas.title: Condition for Three Terms
formulas.formula: Three terms a, b, c are in AP if 2b = a + c
formulas.explanation: The middle term is the average of the other two

realworld.title: Time Management
realworld.description: AP is used in creating schedules where activities increase or decrease by a fixed time interval, like exercise routines or study plans.

formulas.title: Sum of First n Terms
formulas.explanation: Sum of first n terms when first term and common difference are known

formulas.title: Alternative Formula
formulas.formula: Sₙ = n/2 (a + l)
formulas.explanation: Sum when first term (a) and last term (l) are known

notes.title: Understanding Similarity
points: Two figures are similar if they have the same shape but not necessarily the same size.
Corresponding angles are equal, and corresponding sides are in proportion.
The ratio of the areas of two similar figures is equal to the square of the ratio of their corresponding sides.

notes.title: Properties of Similar Figures
points: All circles are similar.
All squares are similar.
All equilateral triangles are similar.
For any two similar polygons, the ratio of their perimeters is equal to the ratio of their corresponding sides.

formulas.title: Area Ratio of Similar Figures
formulas.formula: Area₁/Area₂ = (Side₁/Side₂)²
formulas.explanation: The ratio of the areas of two similar figures is equal to the square of the ratio of their corresponding sides.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Architects use the concept of similarity to create scale models of buildings where all dimensions are proportionally reduced or enlarged.

notes.title: Basic Proportionality Theorem (Thales Theorem)
points: If a line is drawn parallel to one side of a triangle to intersect the other two sides in distinct points, the other two sides are divided in the same ratio.
In ΔABC, if DE ∥ BC, then AD/DB = AE/EC

notes.title: Converse of Basic Proportionality Theorem
points: If a line divides any two sides of a triangle in the same ratio, then the line is parallel to the third side.
This is used to prove that two lines are parallel.

formulas.title: Basic Proportionality Theorem
formulas.formula: In ΔABC, if DE ∥ BC, then AD/DB = AE/EC
formulas.explanation: The line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two sides proportionally.

realworld.title: Surveying
realworld.description: Used to measure heights of tall objects like trees or buildings by creating similar triangles with known measurements.

notes.title: AAA (Angle-Angle-Angle) Similarity
points: If in two triangles, corresponding angles are equal, then their corresponding sides are in the same ratio (or proportion).
This means the two triangles are similar.

notes.title: SSS (Side-Side-Side) Similarity
points: If in two triangles, sides of one triangle are proportional to (i.e., in the same ratio of) the sides of the other triangle, then their corresponding angles are equal.
This means the two triangles are similar.

notes.title: SAS (Side-Angle-Side) Similarity
points: If one angle of a triangle is equal to one angle of the other triangle and the sides including these angles are proportional, then the two triangles are similar.

formulas.title: Similarity Ratio
formulas.formula: For similar triangles ABC and DEF: AB/DE = BC/EF = AC/DF
formulas.explanation: Corresponding sides of similar triangles are in proportion.

realworld.title: Navigation
realworld.description: Used in GPS systems and maritime navigation to determine an object's location by measuring angles from known points.

notes.title: Statement and Proof
points: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.
If a triangle is right-angled at B, then AC² = AB² + BC²
The converse is also true: If AC² = AB² + BC², then angle B is 90°.

notes.title: Applications
points: Used to find the length of the third side when two sides are known.
Helps in determining whether a triangle is right-angled, acute-angled, or obtuse-angled.
Basis for many real-world applications in construction, navigation, and physics.

formulas.title: Pythagorean Theorem
formulas.formula: In right ΔABC, right-angled at B: AC² = AB² + BC²
formulas.explanation: The square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of squares of the other two sides.

formulas.title: Pythagorean Triples
formulas.explanation: Sets of three positive integers that satisfy the Pythagorean theorem.

notes.title: Understanding the Cartesian Plane
points: The coordinate plane is formed by two perpendicular number lines intersecting at the origin (0,0).
The horizontal line is called the x-axis, and the vertical line is called the y-axis.
Any point in the plane can be represented as an ordered pair (x, y), where x is the abscissa and y is the ordinate.

notes.title: Derivation of Distance Formula
points: The distance between two points A(x₁, y₁) and B(x₂, y₂) is given by:
Derived using the Pythagorean theorem by creating a right triangle with the line segment as the hypotenuse.
The difference in x-coordinates gives the base, and the difference in y-coordinates gives the height of the right triangle.

formulas.title: Distance Between Two Points
formulas.formula: Distance = √[(x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²]
formulas.explanation: This formula calculates the straight-line distance between any two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) in the Cartesian plane.

formulas.title: Distance from Origin
formulas.formula: Distance = √(x² + y²)
formulas.explanation: Special case when one point is the origin (0,0).

realworld.title: Navigation Systems
realworld.description: The distance formula is fundamental in GPS technology to calculate the shortest path between two points on Earth's surface, converted from latitude and longitude coordinates.

realworld.title: Sports Analytics
realworld.description: Used in sports analytics to track and analyze player movements on the field, calculating distances covered during a game.

notes.title: Internal Division of a Line Segment
points: The section formula finds the coordinates of a point that divides a line segment joining two points in a given ratio m:n.
The point can divide the segment internally or externally.
For internal division, the ratio m:n is positive.

notes.title: Midpoint Formula
points: A special case of the section formula when the ratio is 1:1.
The midpoint divides the line segment into two equal parts.
Used to find the center point between two locations.

formulas.title: Section Formula (Internal Division)
formulas.formula: P(x,y) = [(mx₂ + nx₁)/(m+n), (my₂ + ny₁)/(m+n)]
formulas.explanation: Finds the coordinates of a point P that divides the line joining A(x₁,y₁) and B(x₂,y₂) internally in the ratio m:n.

formulas.title: Midpoint Formula
formulas.explanation: Finds the midpoint M of the line segment joining points A(x₁,y₁) and B(x₂,y₂).

realworld.title: Architecture and Construction
realworld.description: Used to find the center of mass or centroid of objects, which is crucial in structural engineering and architecture for ensuring stability.

realworld.title: Computer Graphics
realworld.description: Used in computer graphics to scale images proportionally by finding intermediate points between existing coordinates.

notes.title: Using Coordinates
points: The area of a triangle can be calculated when the coordinates of its three vertices are known.
The formula is derived using the concept of determinants in coordinate geometry.
The value is always taken as positive, so we use the absolute value in calculations.

notes.title: Collinearity of Points
points: Three points A, B, and C are collinear if the area formed by them is zero.
This is because three collinear points cannot form a triangle (the area would be zero).
Useful in checking if multiple points lie on the same straight line.

formulas.title: Area of Triangle Formula
formulas.formula: Area = ½ |x₁(y₂ - y₃) + x₂(y₃ - y₁) + x₃(y₁ - y₂)|
formulas.explanation: Calculates the area of a triangle with vertices at (x₁,y₁), (x₂,y₂), and (x₃,y₃). The absolute value ensures the area is always positive.

formulas.title: Condition for Collinearity
formulas.formula: If |x₁(y₂ - y₃) + x₂(y₃ - y₁) + x₃(y₁ - y₂)| = 0
formulas.explanation: If this condition is satisfied, the three points are collinear (lie on the same straight line).

realworld.description: Surveyors use coordinate geometry to calculate the area of irregular plots of land by dividing them into triangles and applying the area formula.

realworld.title: Computer-Aided Design (CAD)
realworld.description: In CAD software, the area formula is used to calculate surface areas of complex shapes by breaking them down into triangular components.

notes.title: Basic Trigonometric Ratios
points: In a right-angled triangle ABC, right-angled at B:
sin θ = Opposite/Hypotenuse = AB/AC
cos θ = Adjacent/Hypotenuse = BC/AC
tan θ = Opposite/Adjacent = AB/BC
The reciprocals of these ratios are:
cosec θ = 1/sin θ = AC/AB
sec θ = 1/cos θ = AC/BC
cot θ = 1/tan θ = BC/AB

notes.title: Relations Between Ratios
points: tan θ = sin θ / cos θ
cot θ = cos θ / sin θ = 1/tan θ
sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
1 + tan²θ = sec²θ
1 + cot²θ = cosec²θ
These identities are fundamental and used throughout trigonometry

formulas.title: Pythagorean Identity
formulas.formula: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
formulas.explanation: This identity holds true for all angles θ and is derived from the Pythagorean theorem applied to the unit circle.

formulas.title: Ratio Relationships
formulas.formula: 1 + tan²θ = sec²θ and 1 + cot²θ = cosec²θ
formulas.explanation: These identities are derived by dividing the Pythagorean identity by cos²θ and sin²θ respectively.

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Trigonometric ratios are used to measure the height of buildings, towers, and mountains using angle measurements from a known distance.

realworld.title: Navigation
realworld.description: Used in navigation to determine the direction and distance between two points when angles are known.

notes.title: Standard Angle Values
points: The trigonometric ratios of 0°, 30°, 45°, 60°, and 90° have standard values that should be memorized:
sin 90° = 1, cos 90° = 0, tan 90° = undefined

notes.title: Memory Techniques
points: For 0° to 90° in order, sin values follow: √0/2, √1/2, √2/2, √3/2, √4/2
cos values follow the reverse order of sin values
tan θ = sin θ / cos θ, which helps derive tan values
Reciprocal identities can be used to find cosec, sec, and cot values

formulas.title: Complementary Angles
formulas.formula: sin(90°-θ) = cos θ, cos(90°-θ) = sin θ, tan(90°-θ) = cot θ
formulas.explanation: The sine of an angle is equal to the cosine of its complement, and vice versa.

formulas.title: Standard Angle Table
formulas.explanation: Standard trigonometric values for common angles that are frequently used in problems.

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: Engineers use standard angle values to design ramps, roofs, and other structures requiring specific angles for optimal functionality and safety.

realworld.title: Art and Design
realworld.description: Artists use standard angle measurements to create accurate perspective in drawings and designs.

notes.title: Fundamental Identities
points: Reciprocal Identities:
cosec θ = 1/sin θ, sec θ = 1/cos θ, cot θ = 1/tan θ
Quotient Identities:
tan θ = sin θ/cos θ, cot θ = cos θ/sin θ
Pythagorean Identities:
sin²θ + cos²θ = 1, 1 + tan²θ = sec²θ, 1 + cot²θ = cosec²θ

notes.title: Proving Identities
points: Start with the more complex side of the identity
Use known identities to simplify the expression
Convert all terms to sines and cosines if needed
Look for opportunities to factor or expand expressions
Work both sides to meet at a common expression if necessary

formulas.title: Pythagorean Identity
formulas.formula: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
formulas.explanation: The fundamental identity from which others can be derived, based on the unit circle.

formulas.title: Derived Identities
formulas.formula: 1 + tan²θ = sec²θ and 1 + cot²θ = cosec²θ
formulas.explanation: These can be derived by dividing the fundamental identity by cos²θ and sin²θ respectively.

realworld.title: Physics
realworld.description: Trigonometric identities are essential in analyzing wave patterns, including sound waves, light waves, and water waves.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Used to analyze forces in different components of structures like bridges and buildings, ensuring stability and safety.

realworld.title: Computer Graphics
realworld.description: Trigonometric identities are fundamental in 3D graphics for rotating objects, calculating lighting, and creating realistic animations.

notes.title: Basic Concepts and Terminology
points: Line of Sight: The line drawn from the eye of the observer to the point being viewed.
Angle of Elevation: The angle between the horizontal and the line of sight when the point being viewed is above the horizontal level.
Angle of Depression: The angle between the horizontal and the line of sight when the point being viewed is below the horizontal level.
The angle of elevation and depression are always measured from the horizontal line.
The angle of elevation of a point P as seen from point A is equal to the angle of depression of point A as seen from point P.

notes.title: Problem-Solving Approach
points: Draw a clear diagram representing the given situation.
Mark all given angles of elevation/depression and distances.
Identify the right triangles in the diagram.
Use appropriate trigonometric ratios (sin, cos, tan) to form equations.
Solve the equations to find the required height or distance.

formulas.title: Basic Trigonometric Ratios
formulas.formula:
In right triangle ABC, right-angled at B:
sin θ = AB/AC
cos θ = BC/AC
tan θ = AB/BC
formulas.explanation: These ratios are fundamental for solving height and distance problems.

formulas.title: Angle of Elevation/Depression Relationship
formulas.formula: Angle of Elevation from A to B = Angle of Depression from B to A
formulas.explanation: The angle of elevation of an object is equal to the angle of depression when the observer and object swap positions.

realworld.title: Surveying and Mapping
realworld.description: Surveyors use trigonometry to measure distances to inaccessible points, create topographical maps, and determine land boundaries.

realworld.title: Aviation
realworld.description: Pilots use angles of elevation and depression to calculate distances to runways and maintain proper altitude during takeoff and landing.

realworld.title: Architecture and Construction
realworld.description: Architects use these concepts to design ramps, staircases, and determine the height of structures based on shadow lengths.

notes.title: Understanding Tangents
points: A tangent to a circle is a line that intersects the circle at exactly one point, called the point of tangency.
The tangent at any point of a circle is perpendicular to the radius through the point of contact.
The lengths of the two tangents drawn from an external point to a circle are equal.
The angle between a tangent and a chord is equal to the angle in the alternate segment.

notes.title: Properties of Tangents
points: At the point of contact, the tangent is perpendicular to the radius.
A line drawn through the end point of a radius and perpendicular to it is a tangent to the circle.
The lengths of two tangents drawn from an external point to a circle are equal.
If two circles touch each other, the point of contact lies on the line joining their centers.

formulas.title: Length of Tangent
formulas.formula: If PT is a tangent from point P to a circle with center O and radius r, then PT = √(OP² - r²)
formulas.explanation: This is derived from the right triangle formed by the radius, tangent, and the line joining the point to the center.

formulas.title: Angle between Tangent and Chord
formulas.formula: The angle between a tangent and a chord is equal to the angle in the alternate segment.
formulas.explanation: This is known as the Alternate Segment Theorem.

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: The concept of tangents is crucial in designing gear systems where smooth transfer of motion between gears is required.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: The principles of tangents are used in the construction of arches and domes to ensure structural integrity and proper weight distribution.

topics.name: Number of Tangents from a Point

notes.title: Position of Point Relative to Circle
points: If a point is inside the circle, no tangent can be drawn to the circle from that point.
If a point is on the circle, exactly one tangent can be drawn to the circle at that point.
If a point is outside the circle, exactly two tangents can be drawn to the circle from that point.

notes.title: Properties of Tangents from External Point
points: The two tangents drawn from an external point to a circle are equal in length.
The line joining the external point to the center of the circle bisects the angle between the two tangents.
The line joining the external point to the center of the circle is the perpendicular bisector of the chord of contact.

formulas.title: Length of Tangent from External Point
formulas.formula: If P is a point outside the circle with center O and radius r, and PT is a tangent, then PT = √(OP² - r²)
formulas.explanation: This is derived using the Pythagorean theorem in the right triangle OPT.

formulas.title: Angle between Two Tangents
formulas.formula: If PA and PB are two tangents from an external point P to a circle, then angle APB = 2 × angle OAP
formulas.explanation: This relates the angle between two tangents to the angle between one tangent and the line joining the point to the center.

realworld.title: Astronomy
realworld.description: The concept of tangents is used in calculating the visibility of celestial bodies and determining when they are tangent to the horizon.

realworld.title: Navigation
realworld.description: In navigation, the concept of tangents helps in determining the visible horizon and calculating distances to objects at sea.

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: The angle at which a billiard ball should be hit to make it rebound off the cushion is determined using the principle that the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection, similar to the tangent property.

topics.name: Perimeter and Area of a Circle

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: The perimeter (circumference) of a circle is the distance around the circle.
The area of a circle is the region enclosed by the circle.
The ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter is a constant called π (pi), approximately 3.14159.
The value of π is the same for all circles, regardless of their size.

notes.title: Key Relationships
points: The diameter (d) of a circle is twice its radius (r): d = 2r
The radius is half of the diameter: r = d/2
The perimeter and area formulas are fundamental to solving problems involving circular shapes.
These concepts are extended to find areas of combinations of plane figures involving circles.

formulas.title: Circumference of a Circle
formulas.formula: C = 2πr or C = πd
formulas.explanation: The distance around the circle, where r is the radius and d is the diameter.

formulas.title: Area of a Circle
formulas.formula: A = πr²
formulas.explanation: The space enclosed within the boundary of the circle.

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: Used in designing wheels, gears, and pipes where precise measurements of circumference and area are crucial.

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Calculating the amount of material needed for circular gardens, fountains, or roundabouts.

topics.name: Areas of Sector and Segment of a Circle

notes.title: Sector of a Circle
points: A sector is the region bounded by two radii and the corresponding arc of the circle.
The angle between the two radii is called the sector angle (θ).
The length of the arc (l) of a sector with angle θ is given by l = (θ/360°) × 2πr

notes.title: Segment of a Circle
points: A segment is the region bounded by a chord and the corresponding arc of the circle.
The area of a segment can be found by subtracting the area of the triangle from the area of the corresponding sector.
For a segment with angle θ, area = (θ/360°) × πr² - ½ r²sinθ

formulas.title: Area of a Sector
formulas.explanation: Where θ is the angle of the sector in degrees and r is the radius of the circle.

formulas.title: Length of an Arc
formulas.explanation: The length of the curved part of the sector's boundary.

formulas.title: Area of a Segment
formulas.formula: A = (θ/360°) × πr² - ½ r²sinθ
formulas.explanation: The area of the segment is the area of the sector minus the area of the triangular portion.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Used in calculating the materials needed for curved structures and decorative elements.

realworld.title: Manufacturing
realworld.description: Sectors are used to represent data in pie charts, where each sector's angle is proportional to the quantity it represents.

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: The design of running tracks involves calculating areas of sectors and segments to mark different racing lanes and field areas.

topics.name: Surface Area of a Combination of Solids

notes.title: Understanding Combined Solids
points: A combined solid is formed when two or more basic solids are joined together.
The surface area of a combination of solids is the sum of the areas of the individual solids minus the areas of the common parts.
Common combinations include: cylinder on a cube, cone on a cylinder, hemisphere on a cube, etc.
When two solids are joined, the area of the contact surface is not included in the total surface area.

notes.title: Problem-Solving Approach
points: Identify all the individual solids that make up the combined shape.
Calculate the surface area of each solid separately.
Subtract the area of the common surface where the solids are joined.
Add up the remaining surface areas to get the total surface area.

formulas.title: Total Surface Area of Combined Solids
formulas.formula: TSA = Σ(Individual Surface Areas) - 2 × (Area of Common Surface)
formulas.explanation: Sum of surface areas of all individual solids minus twice the area of the common surface (since it's counted in both solids).

formulas.title: Lateral Surface Area of Combined Solids
formulas.formula: LSA = Σ(Visible Lateral Surfaces)
formulas.explanation: Sum of only the visible lateral surfaces of the combined shape.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Used in calculating the amount of paint needed for buildings with complex shapes, such as domes on rectangular structures.

realworld.title: Manufacturing
realworld.description: Helps in determining the material required for packaging that combines different geometric shapes.

topics.name: Volume of a Combination of Solids

notes.title: Understanding Volume Combination
points: The volume of a combination of solids is the sum of the volumes of the individual solids.
Unlike surface area, volume is additive when solids are combined.
Common volume combinations include: cone + hemisphere, cylinder + hemisphere, etc.
The volume remains unchanged regardless of how the solids are arranged.

notes.title: Problem-Solving Approach
points: Identify all the individual solids in the combination.
Calculate the volume of each solid separately using the appropriate formula.
Add up the volumes of all individual solids to get the total volume.
Be careful with units and ensure all measurements are in the same unit.

formulas.title: Total Volume of Combined Solids
formulas.formula: V_total = V₁ + V₂ + V₃ + ... + Vₙ
formulas.explanation: The total volume is simply the sum of volumes of all individual solids in the combination.

formulas.title: Common Volume Combinations
formulas.formula:
Cone + Hemisphere: V = (1/3)πr²h + (2/3)πr³
Cylinder + Hemisphere: V = πr²h + (2/3)πr³
formulas.explanation: Common combinations and their volume calculations.

realworld.title: Civil Engineering
realworld.description: Used in calculating the capacity of water tanks that combine cylindrical and hemispherical shapes.

realworld.title: Manufacturing
realworld.description: Helps in determining the amount of material needed for molds that have complex shapes.

notes.title: Understanding Frustum
points: A frustum is the part of a solid (usually a cone or pyramid) that lies between two parallel planes cutting it.
For a cone, it's the portion of a right circular cone between the base and a plane parallel to the base.
The frustum has two circular ends with radii R (larger radius) and r (smaller radius), and height h.
The slant height (l) of the frustum can be found using the Pythagorean theorem.

notes.title: Properties of Frustum
points: The curved surface area of a frustum of a cone is πl(R + r), where l is the slant height.
The total surface area includes the areas of the two circular ends.
The volume of a frustum is (1/3)πh(R² + Rr + r²).
The relationship between slant height (l), height (h), and the two radii is l² = h² + (R - r)².

formulas.title: Curved Surface Area of Frustum
formulas.formula: CSA = πl(R + r)
formulas.explanation: Where l is the slant height, R is the radius of the lower base, and r is the radius of the upper base.

formulas.title: Total Surface Area of Frustum
formulas.formula: TSA = πl(R + r) + πR² + πr²
formulas.explanation: Includes the curved surface area plus the areas of both circular bases.

formulas.title: Volume of Frustum
formulas.formula: V = (1/3)πh(R² + Rr + r²)
formulas.explanation: Where h is the height of the frustum, R is the radius of the lower base, and r is the radius of the upper base.

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: The shape of cooling towers in power plants is often a frustum of a cone to optimize air flow and heat exchange.

realworld.title: Everyday Objects
realworld.description: Many containers like buckets and drinking glasses are frustum-shaped to make them easier to hold and pour.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Ancient and modern monuments often use frustum shapes for their aesthetic appeal and structural stability.

notes.title: Understanding Grouped Data
points: Grouped data is data organized into classes or intervals, with their corresponding frequencies.
The mean (average) of grouped data gives a central value that represents the entire data set.
Three methods to calculate mean: Direct Method, Assumed Mean Method, and Step Deviation Method.
The choice of method depends on the nature of the data and the given information.

notes.title: Calculation Methods
points: Direct Method: Mean = Σ(fᵢxᵢ) / Σfᵢ, where xᵢ is the class mark and fᵢ is the frequency.
Assumed Mean Method: Uses an assumed mean (A) and deviations (dᵢ = xᵢ - A) to simplify calculations.
Step Deviation Method: Further simplifies calculations by using a common factor (h) for class intervals.
Class mark (xᵢ) is calculated as (Lower Limit + Upper Limit) / 2 for each class.

formulas.title: Direct Method Formula
formulas.formula: x̄ = Σ(fᵢxᵢ) / Σfᵢ
formulas.explanation: Where x̄ is the mean, fᵢ is the frequency of the ith class, and xᵢ is the class mark of the ith class.

formulas.title: Assumed Mean Method
formulas.formula: x̄ = A + (Σfᵢdᵢ)/N, where dᵢ = xᵢ - A
formulas.explanation: A is the assumed mean, dᵢ is the deviation from A, and N is the total frequency.

formulas.title: Step Deviation Method
formulas.formula: x̄ = A + h(Σfᵢuᵢ)/N, where uᵢ = (xᵢ - A)/h
formulas.explanation: h is the class width, uᵢ is the step deviation, and A is the assumed mean.

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: Used by teachers to calculate the average marks of students in different subjects to analyze overall class performance.

realworld.title: Business
realworld.description: Businesses use mean to analyze average sales figures over different time periods to identify trends and make forecasts.

notes.title: Understanding Mode
points: The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a data set.
For grouped data, the mode is the value of the variable corresponding to the maximum frequency.
The modal class is the class with the highest frequency in a frequency distribution.
Mode is particularly useful for categorical data where we wish to know the most common category.

notes.title: Calculation Method
points: Find the modal class (class with highest frequency).
Use the formula: Mode = l + [(f₁ - f₀)/(2f₁ - f₀ - f₂)] × h
Where: l = lower limit of modal class, f₁ = frequency of modal class,
f₀ = frequency of class preceding modal class, f₂ = frequency of class succeeding modal class, h = class width.

formulas.title: Mode Formula for Grouped Data
formulas.formula: Mode = l + [(f₁ - f₀)/(2f₁ - f₀ - f₂)] × h
formulas.explanation: l = lower limit of modal class, f₁ = frequency of modal class, f₀ = frequency of class before modal class, f₂ = frequency of class after modal class, h = class width.

realworld.title: Retail
realworld.description: Used to identify the most frequently sold items to optimize stock levels and manage inventory effectively.

realworld.title: Market Research
realworld.description: Helps identify the most popular product features, colors, or price ranges preferred by consumers.

notes.title: Understanding Median
points: The median is the middle value that separates the higher half from the lower half of a data set.
For grouped data, the median is calculated using the cumulative frequency distribution.
The median class is the class where the cumulative frequency reaches or exceeds n/2, where n is the total frequency.
Median is less affected by extreme values than the mean, making it a better measure for skewed distributions.

notes.title: Calculation Method
points: Find the median class where n/2 falls in the cumulative frequency.
Use the formula: Median = l + [(n/2 - cf)/f] × h
Where: l = lower limit of median class, n = total frequency,
cf = cumulative frequency of class before median class, f = frequency of median class, h = class width.

formulas.title: Median Formula for Grouped Data
formulas.formula: Median = l + [(n/2 - cf)/f] × h
formulas.explanation: l = lower limit of median class, n = total frequency, cf = cumulative frequency of class before median class, f = frequency of median class, h = class width.

formulas.title: Empirical Relationship
formulas.formula: 3 Median = Mode + 2 Mean
formulas.explanation: For moderately skewed distributions, there's an approximate relationship between mean, median, and mode.

realworld.title: Real Estate
realworld.description: Used to determine the median house price in a city, which is less affected by extremely high or low property values than the mean.

realworld.title: Income Analysis
realworld.description: Government agencies use median income rather than mean income to better represent what a typical family earns, as it's less affected by extreme values.

notes.title: Basic Concepts of Probability
points: Probability is a measure of the likelihood that an event will occur, ranging from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain).
An experiment is a situation involving chance or probability that leads to results called outcomes.
An event is a single outcome or a collection of outcomes from an experiment.
Theoretical probability is calculated by dividing the number of favorable outcomes by the total number of possible outcomes.

notes.title: Key Terms and Definitions
points: Sample Space (S): The set of all possible outcomes of an experiment.
Event (E): A subset of the sample space.
Equally Likely Events: Events that have the same probability of occurring.
Impossible Event: An event that can never occur (probability = 0).
Sure Event: An event that is certain to occur (probability = 1).

formulas.title: Probability of an Event
formulas.formula: P(E) = Number of favorable outcomes / Total number of possible outcomes
formulas.explanation: The probability of an event E is the ratio of the number of outcomes favorable to E to the total number of possible outcomes, assuming all outcomes are equally likely.

formulas.title: Range of Probability
formulas.explanation: The probability of any event E is always between 0 and 1, inclusive. P(E) = 0 means the event is impossible, P(E) = 1 means the event is certain.

formulas.title: Complementary Events
formulas.explanation: The probability that event E does not occur is equal to 1 minus the probability that it does occur. E' is called the complement of event E.

realworld.title: Weather Forecasting
realworld.description: Meteorologists use probability to predict weather conditions, such as the chance of rain or snow, helping people plan their activities accordingly.

realworld.title: Insurance
realworld.description: Insurance companies use probability to calculate risks and determine premium rates for different types of insurance policies.

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Coaches and players use probability to develop game strategies, such as the likelihood of scoring from different positions on the field.

notes.title: Understanding Chemical Equations
points: A chemical equation is a symbolic representation of a chemical reaction using chemical formulas and symbols.
Reactants are written on the left side, products on the right, separated by an arrow (→) indicating the direction of the reaction.
The equation must satisfy the Law of Conservation of Mass, meaning the number of atoms of each element must be equal on both sides.
State symbols are used to indicate physical states: (s) for solid, (l) for liquid, (g) for gas, and (aq) for aqueous solution.

notes.title: Balancing Chemical Equations
points: Balancing is done by adjusting coefficients (numbers placed before formulas), never by changing subscripts in formulas.
Start by balancing elements that appear in only one compound on each side.
Balance atoms of elements that appear in multiple compounds last (usually hydrogen and oxygen).
Check that all elements are balanced and coefficients are in the simplest whole number ratio.

formulas.title: General Form of Chemical Equation
formulas.formula: Reactants → Products
formulas.explanation: Represents the starting materials (reactants) transforming into new substances (products) during a chemical reaction.

formulas.title: Example: Combustion of Methane
formulas.formula: CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(l)
formulas.explanation: Balanced equation showing the combustion of methane gas in the presence of oxygen to produce carbon dioxide and water.

realworld.title: Environmental Science
realworld.description: Understanding chemical equations helps in analyzing the environmental impact of burning fossil fuels and developing cleaner energy sources.

realworld.title: Food Industry
realworld.description: Chemical equations explain the browning of fruits (enzymatic browning) and help in developing methods to preserve food for longer periods.

notes.title: Combination Reactions
points: Two or more substances combine to form a single product (A + B → AB).
Example: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O (Formation of water).
Often exothermic, releasing heat energy.

notes.title: Decomposition Reactions
points: A single compound breaks down into two or more simpler substances (AB → A + B).
Example: 2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂ (Electrolysis of water).
Often require energy input in the form of heat, light, or electricity.

notes.title: Displacement Reactions
points: A more reactive element displaces a less reactive element from its compound (A + BC → AC + B).
Example: Fe + CuSO₄ → FeSO₄ + Cu (Iron displacing copper).
Follows the reactivity series of metals.

notes.title: Double Displacement Reactions
points: Exchange of ions between two compounds (AB + CD → AD + CB).
Example: AgNO₃ + NaCl → AgCl + NaNO₃ (Formation of silver chloride).
Often results in the formation of a precipitate, gas, or water.

formulas.title: Neutralization Reaction
formulas.formula: Acid + Base → Salt + Water
formulas.explanation: Example: HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O. A type of double displacement reaction where an acid and base react to form salt and water.

formulas.title: Oxidation-Reduction (Redox)
formulas.formula: Zn + CuSO₄ → ZnSO₄ + Cu
formulas.explanation: Zinc undergoes oxidation (loses electrons) while copper undergoes reduction (gains electrons).

realworld.title: Medical Field
realworld.description: Neutralization reactions are used in antacids to treat acidity by neutralizing excess stomach acid (HCl).

realworld.title: Metallurgy
realworld.description: Displacement reactions are used to extract metals from their ores, such as extracting copper from copper sulfate solution using iron.

notes.title: Oxidation
points: Involves the loss of electrons or gain of oxygen/loss of hydrogen.
The substance that undergoes oxidation is called the reducing agent.
Example: 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO (Magnesium is oxidized).

notes.title: Reduction
points: Involves the gain of electrons or loss of oxygen/gain of hydrogen.
The substance that undergoes reduction is called the oxidizing agent.
Example: CuO + H₂ → Cu + H₂O (Copper oxide is reduced).

notes.title: Redox Reactions
points: Reactions where both oxidation and reduction occur simultaneously.
One substance is oxidized while another is reduced.
Example: Zn + CuSO₄ → ZnSO₄ + Cu (Zinc is oxidized, Copper is reduced).

formulas.title: Oxidation Number Rules
formulas.formula:
For elements: 0
For monatomic ions: Equal to charge
Oxygen: -2 (except in peroxides and OF₂)
Hydrogen: +1 (with non-metals), -1 (with metals)
formulas.explanation: Rules for assigning oxidation numbers to elements in compounds.

formulas.title: Balancing Redox Reactions
formulas.formula: Using oxidation number method or half-reaction method
formulas.explanation: Methods to balance complex redox reactions by tracking electron transfer.

realworld.title: Batteries
realworld.description: Redox reactions are the basis of batteries, where chemical energy is converted to electrical energy through electron transfer.

realworld.title: Corrosion
realworld.description: An electrochemical process where iron is oxidized to form rust (hydrated iron(III) oxide) in the presence of oxygen and water.

realworld.title: Respiration
realworld.description: A series of redox reactions where glucose is oxidized to produce energy in living organisms.

topics.name: Chemical Properties of Acids and Bases

notes.title: Properties of Acids
points: Acids are sour in taste and turn blue litmus paper red.
They react with active metals to produce hydrogen gas: Metal + Acid → Salt + Hydrogen gas
They react with metal carbonates and hydrogen carbonates to produce carbon dioxide gas.
They react with bases to form salt and water (neutralization reaction).
Acids are corrosive in nature and can cause burns on skin.

notes.title: Properties of Bases
points: Bases are bitter in taste and turn red litmus paper blue.
They feel soapy to touch and can cause severe burns (caustic).
They react with acids to form salt and water (neutralization).
They react with non-metal oxides to form salt and water.
Strong bases can damage organic materials and cause chemical burns.

formulas.title: Neutralization Reaction
formulas.formula: Acid + Base → Salt + Water
formulas.explanation: Example: HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O. The H⁺ ions from the acid combine with OH⁻ ions from the base to form water.

formulas.title: Reaction with Metals
formulas.formula:
Metal + Acid → Salt + Hydrogen gas
Example: Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl₂ + H₂↑
formulas.explanation: Active metals react with acids to produce corresponding salts and hydrogen gas.

realworld.title: Digestive System
realworld.description: Hydrochloric acid (HCl) in our stomach helps in digestion by killing harmful bacteria and providing an acidic medium for enzyme action.

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Bases like calcium hydroxide (slaked lime) are added to acidic soils to neutralize excess acidity and improve crop yield.

notes.title: Understanding pH
points: pH is a measure of hydrogen ion concentration in a solution.
The scale ranges from 0 to 14, where 7 is neutral (pure water).
pH < 7 indicates acidic solution (more H⁺ ions).
pH > 7 indicates basic/alkaline solution (more OH⁻ ions).
Each pH unit represents a tenfold difference in acidity or basicity.

notes.title: pH in Daily Life
points: Our body maintains blood pH between 7.35-7.45 for proper functioning.
Tooth decay occurs when pH in mouth falls below 5.5 (acidic).
Plants grow best in soil with specific pH ranges.
Rainwater with pH < 5.6 is called acid rain and harms the environment.

formulas.title: pH Calculation
formulas.formula: pH = -log₁₀[H⁺]
formulas.explanation: The negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter.

formulas.title: pOH and pH Relationship
formulas.formula: pH + pOH = 14 (at 25°C)
formulas.explanation: In any aqueous solution at 25°C, the sum of pH and pOH is always 14.

realworld.title: Health
realworld.description: The body maintains blood pH through various buffer systems. Imbalance can lead to conditions like acidosis or alkalosis.

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Farmers test soil pH to determine if lime (to reduce acidity) or sulfur (to reduce alkalinity) needs to be added for optimal crop growth.

notes.title: Types of Salts
points: Normal salts: Formed by complete neutralization (e.g., NaCl, Na₂SO₄).
Acid salts: Contain replaceable hydrogen atoms (e.g., NaHSO₄).
Basic salts: Contain hydroxide ions (e.g., Pb(OH)Cl).
Double salts: Contain more than one cation or anion (e.g., K₂SO₄·Al₂(SO₄)₃·24H₂O).

notes.title: Common Salt (Sodium Chloride)
points: Essential for human body functioning (nerve impulse transmission, muscle contraction).
Used as a preservative in food (pickles, meat).
Raw material for chemicals like sodium hydroxide, baking soda, washing soda, etc.
Used to melt ice on roads during winter.

formulas.title: Preparation of Washing Soda
formulas.formula:
Na₂CO₃·10H₂O (Sodium carbonate decahydrate)
Preparation: NaCl + NH₃ + H₂O + CO₂ → NaHCO₃ + NH₄Cl
2NaHCO₃ → Na₂CO₃ + H₂O + CO₂
Na₂CO₃ + 10H₂O → Na₂CO₃·10H₂O
formulas.explanation: Washing soda is prepared through the Solvay process and used in glass, soap, and paper industries.

formulas.title: Bleaching Powder
formulas.formula:
CaOCl₂ (Calcium oxychloride)
Preparation: Ca(OH)₂ + Cl₂ → CaOCl₂ + H₂O
formulas.explanation: Used for bleaching cotton and linen, disinfecting drinking water, and in the paper industry.

realworld.title: Household
realworld.description: Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) is used in baking, as an antacid, in fire extinguishers, and for cleaning purposes.

realworld.title: Water Treatment
realworld.description: Salts like sodium carbonate are used to remove calcium and magnesium ions from hard water, preventing scale formation in pipes and boilers.

topics.name: Physical and Chemical Properties of Metals

notes.title: Physical Properties of Metals
points: Metals are typically solid at room temperature (except mercury, which is liquid).
They are good conductors of heat and electricity due to the presence of free electrons.
Metals are malleable (can be hammered into thin sheets) and ductile (can be drawn into wires).
They have a shiny appearance (metallic luster) and produce a ringing sound when struck (sonorous).
Metals have high melting and boiling points (except gallium and cesium).

notes.title: Chemical Properties of Metals
points: Metals react with oxygen to form basic oxides (e.g., 4Na + O₂ → 2Na₂O).
They react with water to form metal hydroxides and hydrogen gas (e.g., 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂).
Metals react with acids to produce salt and hydrogen gas (e.g., Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl₂ + H₂).
More reactive metals can displace less reactive metals from their compounds (displacement reactions).

formulas.title: Reaction with Oxygen
formulas.formula:
4M + nO₂ → 2M₂Oₙ
Example: 4Na + O₂ → 2Na₂O
formulas.explanation: Metals react with oxygen to form metal oxides. The nature of oxide formed depends on the metal's reactivity.

formulas.title: Reaction with Water
formulas.formula:
M + nH₂O → M(OH)ₙ + (n/2)H₂
Example: 2K + 2H₂O → 2KOH + H₂
formulas.explanation: Metals react with water to form metal hydroxides and hydrogen gas. The reactivity increases down the group.

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Metals like iron, steel, and aluminum are widely used in construction due to their strength, durability, and malleability.

realworld.title: Electronics
realworld.description: Copper and aluminum are used in electrical wiring due to their excellent electrical conductivity and ductility.

notes.title: Understanding Reactivity Series
points: The reactivity series is a list of metals arranged in order of their decreasing reactivity.
Potassium (K) is the most reactive metal, while gold (Au) is the least reactive.
Metals above hydrogen in the series can displace hydrogen from acids.
A metal can displace any metal below it in the series from its compound.

notes.title: Importance of Reactivity Series
points: Helps predict the outcome of displacement reactions.
Used in the extraction of metals from their ores.
Explains why some metals are found in free state (gold, silver) while others are found as compounds.
Helps in selecting metals for specific purposes based on their reactivity.

formulas.title: Displacement Reaction
formulas.formula:
A + BX → AX + B
Example: Fe + CuSO₄ → FeSO₄ + Cu
formulas.explanation: A more reactive metal (Fe) can displace a less reactive metal (Cu) from its compound.

formulas.title: Thermal Decomposition
formulas.formula: 2Ag₂O → 4Ag + O₂
formulas.explanation: Metals low in the reactivity series (like silver) can be obtained by thermal decomposition of their oxides.

realworld.title: Metallurgy
realworld.description: The reactivity series determines the method of extraction of metals from their ores (electrolysis for highly reactive metals, reduction for moderately reactive, and roasting/smelting for less reactive metals).

realworld.title: Jewelry Making
realworld.description: Less reactive metals like gold, silver, and platinum are used in jewelry because they don't corrode or react with air and water.

notes.title: Metallurgy Process
points: Concentration of ore: Removal of impurities (gangue) from the ore.
Conversion to oxide: Roasting (sulphide ores) or calcination (carbonate ores).
Reduction: Conversion of metal oxide to metal using suitable reducing agents.
Refining: Purification of the extracted metal.

notes.title: Extraction Methods Based on Reactivity
points: Highly reactive metals (K, Na, Ca, Mg, Al): Extracted by electrolysis of their molten chlorides or oxides.
Moderately reactive metals (Zn, Fe, Pb, Cu): Extracted by reduction of their oxides with carbon or carbon monoxide.
Less reactive metals (Hg, Ag): Extracted by heating their oxides or by roasting their sulphides.

formulas.title: Extraction of Iron (Blast Furnace)
formulas.formula:
2Fe₂O₃ + 3C → 4Fe + 3CO₂
Fe₂O₃ + 3CO → 2Fe + 3CO₂
formulas.explanation: Iron is extracted from its oxide (haematite) by reduction with carbon (coke) and carbon monoxide in a blast furnace.

formulas.title: Aluminum Extraction (Hall-Heroult Process)
formulas.formula: 2Al₂O₃ → 4Al + 3O₂
formulas.explanation: Aluminum is extracted from bauxite (Al₂O₃.2H₂O) by electrolysis of molten alumina in cryolite (Na₃AlF₆).

realworld.title: Industrial Production
realworld.description: The blast furnace process is crucial for producing pig iron, which is further processed into various types of steel used in construction, automobiles, and appliances.

realworld.title: Recycling
realworld.description: Recycling metals like aluminum saves up to 95% of the energy required for primary production, making it an environmentally friendly practice.

notes.title: Covalent Bonding in Carbon
points: Carbon forms covalent bonds by sharing electrons with other atoms to complete its octet (4 valence electrons).
It can form single (C-C), double (C=C), or triple (C≡C) covalent bonds with other carbon atoms.
Carbon can form long chains, branched chains, and rings due to its property of catenation.
Tetravalency of carbon allows it to form four covalent bonds with other atoms.

notes.title: Allotropes of Carbon
points: Diamond: Hardest natural substance, each carbon atom is tetrahedrally bonded to four others.
Graphite: Soft and slippery, consists of hexagonal layers that can slide over each other.
Fullerenes: Spherical molecules of carbon atoms (e.g., C60 - Buckminsterfullerene).
Graphene: Single layer of graphite, extremely strong and excellent conductor of electricity.

formulas.title: Methane Formation
formulas.formula: C + 4H → CH₄
formulas.explanation: Carbon forms four single covalent bonds with four hydrogen atoms to form methane, a simple organic compound.

formulas.title: Ethene Formation
formulas.formula: 2C + 4H → C₂H₄ (H₂C=CH₂)
formulas.explanation: Carbon forms a double bond with another carbon atom and single bonds with hydrogen atoms to form ethene.

realworld.title: Nanotechnology
realworld.description: Cylindrical molecules of carbon with exceptional strength and electrical conductivity, used in electronics and materials science.

realworld.title: Industrial Applications
realworld.description: Graphite is used as a dry lubricant in machines where oil cannot be used, such as in space applications.

notes.title: Catenation
points: Carbon's unique ability to form bonds with other carbon atoms to form long chains and rings.
This property allows for the formation of millions of organic compounds.
The C-C bond is very strong, making these compounds stable.

notes.title: Isomerism
points: Compounds with same molecular formula but different structural arrangements are called isomers.
Example: Butane (C₄H₁₀) has two isomers - n-butane and isobutane.
This property increases the number of possible carbon compounds.

formulas.title: Isomers of Pentane
formulas.formula: C₅H₁₂ (n-pentane, isopentane, neopentane)
formulas.explanation: Same molecular formula but different structural arrangements, showing chain isomerism.

formulas.title: Functional Group Isomerism
formulas.formula: C₂H₆O (Ethanol: CH₃CH₂OH, Dimethyl ether: CH₃OCH₃)
formulas.explanation: Same molecular formula but different functional groups (alcohol vs ether).

realworld.title: Petroleum Industry
realworld.description: The various hydrocarbons in petroleum are separated by fractional distillation based on their different boiling points.

realworld.title: Pharmaceuticals
realworld.description: Isomerism is crucial in drug design as different isomers can have different biological activities.

notes.title: Common Functional Groups
points: Hydroxyl (-OH): Present in alcohols (e.g., ethanol).
Carboxyl (-COOH): Present in carboxylic acids (e.g., acetic acid).
Aldehyde (-CHO): Present in aldehydes (e.g., formaldehyde).
Ketone (-CO-): Present in ketones (e.g., acetone).

notes.title: Homologous Series
points: A series of compounds with the same functional group and similar chemical properties.
Each successive member differs by a -CH₂- unit.
Example: Methane (CH₄), Ethane (C₂H₆), Propane (C₃H₈) form a homologous series of alkanes.

formulas.title: Alcohol Functional Group
formulas.formula:
R-OH
Example: CH₃CH₂OH (Ethanol)
formulas.explanation: The -OH group makes the molecule polar and capable of hydrogen bonding.

formulas.title: Carboxylic Acid
formulas.formula:
R-COOH
Example: CH₃COOH (Acetic acid)
formulas.explanation: The -COOH group makes the compound acidic due to the ability to donate a proton.

realworld.title: Food Industry
realworld.description: Esters (R-COO-R') are responsible for the smell of many fruits and are used as artificial flavorings.

realworld.title: Medicine
realworld.description: Ethanol (C₂H₅OH) is used as an antiseptic and in hand sanitizers due to its ability to kill microorganisms.

notes.title: Saponification
points: The process of making soap by the hydrolysis of fats and oils with an alkali.
Fat + Sodium hydroxide → Glycerol + Soap
Example: Glyceryl stearate + NaOH → Glycerol + Sodium stearate (soap).

notes.title: Cleansing Action
points: Soap molecules have a hydrophobic (water-repelling) tail and hydrophilic (water-attracting) head.
The hydrophobic tail attaches to grease and oil, while the hydrophilic head remains in water.
This forms micelles that help in removing dirt when rinsed with water.

formulas.title: Saponification Reaction
formulas.formula: (C₁₇H₃₅COO)₃C₃H₅ + 3NaOH → 3C₁₇H₃₅COONa + C₃H₅(OH)₃
formulas.explanation: Glyceryl stearate reacts with sodium hydroxide to form sodium stearate (soap) and glycerol.

formulas.title: Structure of Soap Molecule
formulas.formula: CH₃(CH₂)₁₆COO⁻ Na⁺
formulas.explanation: Long hydrocarbon chain (hydrophobic) and ionic end (hydrophilic) that enables cleaning action.

realworld.title: Household Cleaning
realworld.description: Detergents are more effective than soaps in hard water as they don't form scum with calcium and magnesium ions.

realworld.title: Environmental Impact
realworld.description: Soaps are biodegradable but less effective in hard water, while some detergents can be non-biodegradable and cause water pollution.

notes.title: Modes of Nutrition
points: Autotrophic Nutrition: Organisms synthesize their own food using sunlight (photosynthesis) or chemical energy (chemosynthesis).
Heterotrophic Nutrition: Organisms obtain food from other organisms (e.g., humans, animals, fungi).
Photosynthesis equation: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + light energy → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂
Stomata are tiny pores on leaves that facilitate gas exchange during photosynthesis.

notes.title: Human Digestive System
points: Mouth: Mechanical digestion by teeth, chemical digestion by salivary amylase.
Stomach: Acidic environment (HCl) and pepsin break down proteins.
Small Intestine: Major site of digestion and absorption (villi increase surface area).
Large Intestine: Absorbs water and forms feces.

formulas.title: Photosynthesis
formulas.formula: 6CO₂ + 12H₂O + light energy → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ + 6H₂O
formulas.explanation: The process by which green plants synthesize food using carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight in the presence of chlorophyll.

formulas.title: Aerobic Respiration
formulas.formula: C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + 38 ATP
formulas.explanation: The complete breakdown of glucose in the presence of oxygen to release energy, carbon dioxide, and water.

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Understanding photosynthesis helps farmers optimize conditions (light, water, CO₂) to maximize crop production.

realworld.title: Health & Nutrition
realworld.description: Knowledge of nutrition helps in planning balanced diets containing carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals in proper proportions.

notes.title: Types of Respiration
points: Aerobic Respiration: Occurs in mitochondria, requires oxygen, produces more energy (38 ATP/glucose).
Anaerobic Respiration: Occurs in cytoplasm, doesn't require oxygen, produces less energy (2 ATP/glucose).
In humans, anaerobic respiration in muscles during heavy exercise produces lactic acid, causing muscle fatigue.
Yeast undergoes alcoholic fermentation: C₆H₁₂O₆ → 2C₂H₅OH + 2CO₂ + 2ATP

notes.title: Human Respiratory System
points: Nostrils → Nasal cavity → Pharynx → Larynx → Trachea → Bronchi → Bronchioles → Alveoli.
Alveoli are the site of gas exchange (O₂ in, CO₂ out) due to their thin walls and rich blood supply.
Diaphragm and intercostal muscles help in breathing movements.

formulas.title: Anaerobic Respiration in Muscles
formulas.formula: C₆H₁₂O₆ → 2C₃H₆O₃ + 2ATP
formulas.explanation: Glucose is converted to lactic acid in muscle cells during oxygen deficiency, producing less energy.

formulas.title: Gaseous Exchange in Alveoli
formulas.formula:
O₂ (alveolar air) → Blood
CO₂ (blood) → Alveolar air
formulas.explanation: Oxygen diffuses from alveoli to blood, while carbon dioxide diffuses from blood to alveoli.

realworld.title: Medical Field
realworld.description: Knowledge of respiration helps in treating conditions like asthma, COPD, and in designing ventilators for patients with breathing difficulties.

realworld.title: Food Industry
realworld.description: Anaerobic respiration by yeast is used in baking (bread making) and brewing (alcohol production).

notes.title: Human Circulatory System
points: Heart: Four-chambered (2 atria, 2 ventricles), pumps blood throughout the body.
Blood Vessels: Arteries (carry oxygenated blood away from heart), Veins (carry deoxygenated blood to heart), Capillaries (site of exchange).
Blood Components: RBCs (carry O₂), WBCs (immunity), Platelets (clotting), Plasma (liquid matrix).

notes.title: Plant Transport System
points: Xylem: Transports water and minerals from roots to other parts (unidirectional).
Phloem: Transports food from leaves to other parts (bidirectional).
Transpiration: Loss of water vapor from aerial parts, helps in water movement and cooling.

formulas.title: Cardiac Output
formulas.formula: Cardiac Output = Stroke Volume × Heart Rate
formulas.explanation: The volume of blood pumped by each ventricle per minute, typically about 5 liters at rest.

formulas.title: Blood Pressure
formulas.formula: BP = Cardiac Output × Peripheral Resistance
formulas.explanation: Normal BP is 120/80 mmHg (systolic/diastolic).

realworld.title: Medical Diagnostics
realworld.description: Blood analysis helps diagnose various conditions like anemia, infections, and clotting disorders.

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Understanding plant water transport helps in developing efficient irrigation systems and drought-resistant crops.

notes.title: Human Excretory System
points: Kidneys: Filter blood, remove waste as urine, maintain water and electrolyte balance.
Nephron: Functional unit of kidney, filters blood and forms urine.
Processes: Filtration (in glomerulus), Reabsorption (in tubules), Secretion (in tubules).

notes.title: Excretion in Plants
points: Plants remove waste through various methods:
- Oxygen (photosynthesis byproduct) is released through stomata.
- Excess water is lost through transpiration.
- Waste products may be stored in leaves (shed later) or in cellular vacuoles.

formulas.title: Urine Formation Rate
formulas.formula: Urine Output = Filtration - Reabsorption + Secretion
formulas.explanation: The amount of urine formed depends on the balance between filtration, reabsorption, and secretion in nephrons.

formulas.title: Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)
formulas.formula: Normal GFR = 90-120 mL/min
formulas.explanation: The rate at which blood is filtered by the glomeruli in the kidneys, an important indicator of kidney function.

realworld.title: Medical Treatment
realworld.description: Artificial filtration of blood when kidneys fail, based on principles of excretion and selective reabsorption.

realworld.title: Environmental Science
realworld.description: Understanding natural excretion processes helps in developing better waste treatment and recycling systems.

notes.title: Components of Nervous System
points: Neurons: Basic structural and functional units of the nervous system, consisting of cell body, dendrites, and axon.
Central Nervous System (CNS): Brain and spinal cord, responsible for processing information.
Peripheral Nervous System (PNS): Nerves that connect CNS to the rest of the body.
Reflex Action: Quick, automatic response to stimuli (e.g., withdrawing hand from hot objects).

notes.title: Human Brain
points: Forebrain: Includes cerebrum (thinking, reasoning, memory), thalamus (relay station), and hypothalamus (controls hunger, thirst, body temperature).
Midbrain: Controls reflex movements of head, neck, and trunk in response to visual and auditory stimuli.
Hindbrain: Includes cerebellum (balance and posture), pons (regulates respiration), and medulla (controls involuntary actions like heartbeat and breathing).

formulas.title: Nerve Impulse Transmission
formulas.formula:
Resting Potential: -70mV
Action Potential: +40mV
formulas.explanation: Neurons maintain an electrical potential difference across their membrane. When stimulated, this changes, creating an electrical impulse.

formulas.title: Synaptic Transmission
formulas.formula: Presynaptic neuron → Neurotransmitter release → Synaptic cleft → Postsynaptic neuron
formulas.explanation: Chemical signals (neurotransmitters) cross the synapse to transmit impulses between neurons.

realworld.title: Medical Field
realworld.description: Understanding the nervous system helps in treating conditions like Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, and epilepsy.

realworld.title: Sports Science
realworld.description: Athletes train to improve their reflex actions for better performance in sports.

notes.title: Plant Movements
points: Tropic Movements: Directional growth responses to environmental stimuli (e.g., phototropism, geotropism).
Nastic Movements: Non-directional responses to stimuli (e.g., touch-me-not plant leaves drooping when touched).
Hormonal Control: Plant hormones like auxins, gibberellins, and cytokinins regulate growth and development.

notes.title: Plant Hormones
points: Auxins: Promote cell elongation, phototropism, and apical dominance.
Gibberellins: Stimulate stem elongation, seed germination, and flowering.
Cytokinins: Promote cell division and delay leaf senescence.
Abscisic Acid: Inhibits growth, promotes seed dormancy, and closes stomata during water stress.
Ethylene: Promotes fruit ripening and leaf abscission.

formulas.title: Auxin Distribution
formulas.formula:
Shaded side: More auxin → More cell elongation
Lighted side: Less auxin → Less cell elongation
formulas.explanation: Unequal distribution of auxin causes differential growth, resulting in phototropism.

formulas.title: Stomatal Regulation
formulas.formula:
CO₂ + H₂O + light → C₆H₁₂O₆ + O₂ (Open)
Abscisic acid → K⁺ efflux → Stomatal closure (Drought)
formulas.explanation: Stomata open for photosynthesis and close to prevent water loss during drought.

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Farmers use synthetic plant hormones to improve crop yield, control weed growth, and manage fruit ripening.

realworld.title: Horticulture
realworld.description: Plant hormones are used in tissue culture to produce large numbers of identical plants from a small piece of plant tissue.

notes.title: Endocrine System
points: Hormones: Chemical messengers secreted by endocrine glands directly into the bloodstream.
Pituitary Gland: 'Master gland' that controls other endocrine glands.
Thyroid Gland: Produces thyroxine, which regulates metabolism.
Adrenal Gland: Produces adrenaline (fight or flight response) and cortisol (stress response).

notes.title: Feedback Mechanisms
points: Negative Feedback: Maintains homeostasis by reversing changes (e.g., blood sugar regulation by insulin and glucagon).
Positive Feedback: Amplifies changes (e.g., oxytocin release during childbirth).
Disorders: Diabetes (insulin deficiency), Goiter (iodine deficiency), Dwarfism/Gigantism (growth hormone imbalance).

formulas.title: Blood Sugar Regulation
formulas.formula:
High blood sugar → Pancreas secretes insulin → Cells take up glucose → Blood sugar decreases
Low blood sugar → Pancreas secretes glucagon → Liver releases glucose → Blood sugar increases
formulas.explanation: Maintains blood glucose levels within a narrow range.

formulas.title: Adrenaline Response
formulas.formula: Stress → Hypothalamus → Adrenal medulla → Adrenaline → Increased heart rate, breathing, blood pressure
formulas.explanation: Prepares the body for 'fight or flight' response to emergencies.

realworld.title: Medicine
realworld.description: Used to treat conditions like diabetes (insulin), growth disorders (growth hormone), and thyroid disorders (thyroxine).

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Athletes are tested for performance-enhancing hormones like anabolic steroids to ensure fair competition.

notes.title: Types of Asexual Reproduction
points: Binary Fission: Single-celled organisms split into two identical cells (e.g., Amoeba, Paramecium).
Budding: New organism grows out of the parent (e.g., Hydra, yeast).
Fragmentation: Organism breaks into pieces, each growing into a new individual (e.g., Spirogyra, Planaria).
Spore Formation: Specialized cells (spores) develop into new individuals (e.g., Rhizopus, ferns).
Vegetative Propagation: New plants grow from vegetative parts like roots, stems, or leaves (e.g., potato tubers, onion bulbs).

notes.title: Advantages and Disadvantages
points: Advantages: Faster process, requires only one parent, preserves genetic stability, rapid population growth.
Disadvantages: No genetic variation, less adaptability to environmental changes, accumulation of harmful mutations.

formulas.title: Population Growth in Binary Fission
