formulas.formula: Devolution of Powers + Financial Autonomy + People's Participation = Level of Decentralization
formulas.explanation: Measures the extent of decentralization in a political system.

formulas.title: Grassroots Democracy Index
formulas.formula: Participation + Accountability + Responsiveness = Democratic Quality at Local Level
formulas.explanation: Assesses the health of democracy at the local government level.

realworld.title: Kerala's People's Plan Campaign
realworld.description: Kerala's decentralized planning involves local communities in planning and implementing development projects.

realworld.title: West Bengal's Panchayat System
realworld.description: One of the most successful models of Panchayati Raj with significant devolution of powers and resources to local bodies.

notes.title: Gender Division in Society
points: Gender division is a form of hierarchical social division that exists in most societies.
It is based on social expectations and stereotypes rather than biological differences.
Women face disadvantage, discrimination, and oppression in various ways in patriarchal societies.
The feminist movement has challenged the traditional gender roles and fought for equal rights.

notes.title: Women's Political Representation
points: The proportion of women in Indian Parliament (Lok Sabha) has never reached even 15% of total seats.
The Women's Reservation Bill, proposing 33% reservation for women in Parliament, is still pending.
Panchayati Raj institutions have 33% reservation for women, leading to more than 14 lakh elected women representatives.
Women's organizations and movements have been active in raising women's issues in politics.

formulas.title: Gender Parity Index
formulas.formula: Value for Girls / Value for Boys = Gender Parity Index
formulas.explanation: Measures the relative access to resources and opportunities between males and females.

formulas.title: Women's Empowerment Index
formulas.formula: Political Participation + Economic Participation + Educational Attainment = Empowerment Score
formulas.explanation: Assesses the level of women's empowerment across different dimensions.

realworld.title: Self-Help Groups (SHGs)
realworld.description: SHGs have empowered rural women economically and socially, giving them greater voice in household and community decisions.

realworld.title: Beti Bachao Beti Padhao
realworld.description: Government initiative to address the declining child sex ratio and promote education for the girl child.

notes.title: Communalism in India
points: Communalism is a situation when a particular community tries to promote its own interests at the expense of others.
It leads to the belief that people belonging to different religions cannot live as equal citizens within one nation.
Communal politics is based on the idea that religion is the principal basis of social community.
Communal violence has been a major challenge to India's secular fabric.

notes.title: Secularism in India
points: The Indian Constitution does not give a special status to any religion.
The Constitution prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion (Articles 15 and 16).
The State cannot compel any citizen to pay taxes for the promotion of any particular religion (Article 27).
The Constitution gives the right to all religious communities to establish and maintain their educational institutions (Article 30).

formulas.title: Communal Harmony Index
formulas.formula: Interfaith Interactions - Communal Incidents = Communal Harmony Score
formulas.explanation: Measures the level of peaceful coexistence among different religious communities.

formulas.title: Secularism Index
formulas.formula: Religious Freedom + State Neutrality + Minority Rights = Secularism Score
formulas.explanation: Assesses the degree of secularism in a political system.

realworld.title: Shah Bano Case
realworld.description: The 1985 Supreme Court judgment highlighted the tension between religious personal laws and gender justice.

realworld.title: Babri Masjid-Ram Janmabhoomi Dispute
realworld.description: A long-standing religious dispute that had significant political implications in India.

notes.title: Caste in Contemporary India
points: The caste system is a hierarchical social division based on birth, with Brahmins at the top and Dalits (Scheduled Castes) at the bottom.
The practice of untouchability was abolished by the Constitution (Article 17).
The government has implemented reservation policies for Scheduled Castes (15%), Scheduled Tribes (7.5%), and OBCs (27%) in education and government jobs.
Despite constitutional provisions, caste-based discrimination and atrocities continue to exist.

notes.title: Caste in Politics
points: Political parties often nominate candidates from different castes to muster necessary support for winning elections.
Caste-based political parties have emerged, especially in states like Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.
Universal adult franchise and the principle of one-person-one-vote have given marginalized castes a voice in democratic politics.
Caste alone cannot determine election results as voters make choices based on multiple factors.

formulas.title: Caste Representation Index
formulas.formula: Proportion in Population - Proportion in Legislature = Representation Gap
formulas.explanation: Measures the gap between a caste group's population share and its political representation.

formulas.title: Social Justice Index
formulas.formula: Access to Education + Economic Opportunities + Political Representation = Social Justice Score
formulas.explanation: Assesses the level of social justice for marginalized caste groups.

realworld.title: Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP)
realworld.description: A political party formed to represent the interests of Dalits and other marginalized sections of society.

realworld.title: Mandal Commission
realworld.description: The implementation of the Mandal Commission report in 1990 led to 27% reservation for Other Backward Classes in government jobs.

notes.title: Different Notions of Development
points: Development means different things to different people based on their aspirations and life situations.
For a farmer in Punjab, development might mean higher support prices for crops, while for an urban youth, it might mean better job opportunities.
For a girl from a poor family, development might mean the freedom to go to school, while for her parents, it might mean having enough to eat.
Development involves thinking about and working towards social and economic equality.

notes.title: Income and Development
points: Income is considered an important attribute of development as it helps fulfill various needs.
However, money (or material possessions) cannot buy all the things needed for a good life.
People also seek non-material aspects like freedom, security, respect for others, and equal treatment.
The quality of life depends on both material and non-material factors.

formulas.title: Development Index
formulas.formula: Economic Growth + Social Progress + Environmental Sustainability = Development Score
formulas.explanation: Measures overall development by considering multiple dimensions beyond just economic factors.

formulas.title: Quality of Life Index
formulas.formula: Material Well-being + Health + Education + Social Relationships = Quality of Life
formulas.explanation: Assesses the general well-being of individuals and societies based on multiple indicators.

realworld.title: Bhutan's Gross National Happiness
realworld.description: Bhutan measures development through Gross National Happiness, emphasizing sustainable development, cultural values, and good governance.

realworld.title: Kerala Development Model
realworld.description: Kerala has achieved high human development indicators (literacy, life expectancy) despite relatively lower per capita income, showing that development is not just about economic growth.

notes.title: Income as a Development Goal
points: Higher income is an important goal for most people as it provides the means to access various goods and services.
However, people also have non-income goals such as equal treatment, freedom, security, and respect.
A safe and secure environment may be more important than more income for some people.
The developmental goals that people have are not only about better income but also about other important things in life.

notes.title: Conflicting Development Goals
points: Different persons could have different as well as conflicting notions of development.
Industrialists may want more dams for electricity, but this might displace tribal communities from their lands.
A girl expects as much freedom and opportunity as her brother, but the brother may not like this.
The challenge of development is to balance these conflicting goals.

formulas.title: Well-being Index
formulas.formula: Income + Education + Health + Social Inclusion = Well-being Score
formulas.explanation: Measures overall well-being by considering multiple dimensions of human development.

formulas.title: Development Trade-off Index
formulas.formula: Economic Growth - Environmental Degradation = Sustainable Development Score
formulas.explanation: Assesses the balance between economic progress and environmental sustainability.

realworld.title: Narmada Bachao Andolan
realworld.description: A social movement highlighting the conflict between large dam projects and the rights of displaced communities.

realworld.title: Self-Help Groups (SHGs)
realworld.description: SHGs have empowered rural women economically and socially, showing how development can address multiple goals simultaneously.

notes.title: Comparing Different Countries
points: Countries are often compared based on their per capita income, which is the total income of the country divided by its population.
The World Bank classifies countries as high-income, middle-income, and low-income countries based on per capita income.
However, per capita income doesn't show how this income is distributed among people in a country.
Other indicators like infant mortality rate, literacy rate, and net attendance ratio provide a better picture of development.

notes.title: Human Development Report
points: Published by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), it compares countries based on the Human Development Index (HDI).
HDI considers life expectancy, education (adult literacy rate and gross enrollment ratio), and per capita income.
Countries with per capita income of US$ 12,055 or more (as per 2017) are considered rich countries.
India's HDI rank was 131 out of 189 countries in the 2020 report.

formulas.title: Human Development Index (HDI)
formulas.formula: (Life Expectancy Index + Education Index + Income Index) / 3 = HDI
formulas.explanation: A composite index measuring average achievement in three basic dimensions of human development.

formulas.title: Per Capita Income
formulas.formula: Total National Income / Total Population = Per Capita Income
formulas.explanation: Measures the average income earned per person in a given area in a specified year.

realworld.title: Kerala vs Punjab
realworld.description: Kerala has better human development indicators than Punjab despite having lower per capita income, showing that income alone doesn't determine development.

realworld.title: China's Development Model
realworld.description: China's rapid economic growth has lifted millions out of poverty but has also led to environmental degradation and income inequality.

notes.title: Sustainable Development
points: Sustainable development means development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.
It requires the conservation of resources so that they are available for future generations.
It balances economic growth with environmental protection and social equity.
The concept of sustainable development was popularized by the Brundtland Commission in 1987.

notes.title: Challenges to Sustainable Development
points: Over-exploitation of natural resources beyond their regeneration capacity.
Environmental degradation due to pollution and climate change.
Growing economic inequalities within and between countries.
The need to balance present needs with the needs of future generations.

formulas.title: Ecological Footprint
formulas.formula: Biological Capacity - Ecological Footprint = Ecological Deficit/Reserve
formulas.explanation: Measures human demand on nature against nature's capacity to regenerate resources and absorb waste.

formulas.title: Sustainable Development Index
formulas.formula: (Economic + Social + Environmental Performance) / 3 = SDI
formulas.explanation: Measures a country's overall progress towards sustainable development goals.

realworld.title: Chipko Movement
realworld.description: A forest conservation movement in India where people hugged trees to prevent their felling, highlighting the importance of sustainable development.

realworld.title: Solar Energy in India
realworld.description: India's National Solar Mission aims to promote sustainable growth while addressing energy security challenges.

notes.title: Primary Sector
points: Also known as the agriculture and related sector, it includes activities that directly use natural resources.
Examples: Agriculture, dairy, fishing, forestry, mining, and quarrying.
Contributes about 16-17% to India's GDP (as of 2023) but employs about 44% of the workforce.
Known as the 'primary' sector because it forms the base for all other products.

notes.title: Secondary Sector
points: Also called the industrial or manufacturing sector, it transforms raw materials into finished goods.
Examples: Manufacturing, construction, electricity, gas, and water supply.
Contributes about 28-30% to India's GDP and employs about 25% of the workforce.
Includes both large-scale industries (automobiles, steel) and small-scale industries (handicrafts, textiles).

notes.title: Tertiary Sector
points: Also known as the service sector, it provides services rather than goods.
Examples: Banking, transport, communication, education, health, tourism, and IT services.
Largest contributor to India's GDP (about 55-57%) and employs about 31% of the workforce.
Has become the most important sector in terms of GDP contribution in recent years.

formulas.title: Sectoral Contribution to GDP
formulas.formula: (Sector's GVA / Total GVA) × 100 = Sector's % share in GDP
formulas.explanation: Calculates the percentage contribution of each sector to the total Gross Value Added (GVA) of the economy.

formulas.title: Employment Elasticity
formulas.formula: % Change in Employment / % Change in GDP = Employment Elasticity
formulas.explanation: Measures how employment changes with economic growth in each sector.

realworld.title: Green Revolution
realworld.description: The Green Revolution in the 1960s transformed Indian agriculture through high-yielding varieties of seeds, irrigation, and chemical fertilizers, making India self-sufficient in food grains.

realworld.title: Make in India Initiative
realworld.description: Launched in 2014 to encourage companies to manufacture in India, aiming to increase the manufacturing sector's contribution to GDP to 25% by 2025.

notes.title: Historical Perspective
points: In the early stages of development, the primary sector was the most important sector of economic activity.
As development progressed, the secondary sector became dominant (industrial revolution).
In developed economies, the tertiary sector becomes the most important sector (post-industrial society).
India is currently in a phase of transition from a primarily agrarian to a service-led economy.

notes.title: Interdependence of Sectors
points: All three sectors are interdependent - the development of one sector affects the others.
Example: Agriculture (primary) provides raw materials to industries (secondary), which then need transport (tertiary) to reach consumers.
The service sector supports both agriculture and industry through banking, insurance, transport, etc.
A balanced growth of all three sectors is essential for overall economic development.

formulas.title: Structural Transformation Index
formulas.formula: (Tertiary Sector Employment / Total Employment) / (Primary Sector Employment / Total Employment)
formulas.explanation: Measures the structural transformation from primary to tertiary sector in an economy.

formulas.title: Sectoral Growth Rate
formulas.formula: (Current Year GVA - Previous Year GVA) / Previous Year GVA × 100 = Growth Rate %
formulas.explanation: Calculates the annual growth rate of each sector's Gross Value Added.

realworld.title: IT Boom in India
realworld.description: The growth of the IT and ITES sector in India since the 1990s has made services the largest contributor to GDP, showcasing how a developing country can leapfrog to services.

realworld.title: China's Manufacturing Dominance
realworld.description: China's focus on manufacturing has made it the 'factory of the world', demonstrating how the secondary sector can drive economic growth and employment.

topics.name: Division of Sectors as Organized and Unorganized

notes.title: Organized Sector
points: Enterprises registered by the government and have to follow its rules and regulations.
Workers enjoy job security, fixed working hours, paid leaves, and other benefits like provident fund and gratuity.
Examples: Government employees, employees in registered companies, public sector enterprises.
Accounts for about 10% of India's workforce but contributes significantly to GDP.

notes.title: Unorganized Sector
points: Small and scattered units outside government control, with low-paid and insecure jobs.
Workers don't enjoy job security, fixed working hours, or other benefits.
Examples: Small farmers, agricultural laborers, street vendors, domestic workers.
Employs about 90% of India's workforce but contributes less to GDP compared to the organized sector.

formulas.title: Formalization Rate
formulas.formula: (Workers in Organized Sector / Total Workforce) × 100 = Formalization Rate %
formulas.explanation: Measures the percentage of workforce in the organized/formal sector.

formulas.title: Productivity Gap
formulas.formula: Output per Worker (Organized) - Output per Worker (Unorganized) = Productivity Gap
formulas.explanation: Measures the difference in productivity between organized and unorganized sectors.

realworld.title: MGNREGA
realworld.description: The Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act provides 100 days of wage employment per year to rural households, bringing some security to unorganized sector workers.

realworld.title: e-Shram Portal
realworld.description: Launched in 2021, it creates a national database of unorganized workers to help them access social security benefits.

notes.title: Public Sector
points: Enterprises owned and managed by the government.
Aim to provide public welfare rather than just earn profits.
Examples: Indian Railways, BSNL, ONGC, SAIL, SBI.
Plays a crucial role in strategic sectors like defense, atomic energy, and space research.

notes.title: Private Sector
points: Enterprises owned and managed by private individuals or companies.
Main objective is to earn profits.
Examples: Reliance Industries, TATA Steel, Infosys, HDFC Bank.
Has grown significantly since the economic liberalization in 1991.

notes.title: Joint Sector
points: Enterprises jointly owned by the government and private entrepreneurs.
Combines the efficiency of the private sector with the welfare orientation of the public sector.
Examples: Maruti Suzuki India Limited, Cochin International Airport.
Helps in mobilizing resources and sharing risks between public and private sectors.

formulas.title: Public Sector Investment Multiplier
formulas.formula: Change in National Income / Change in Public Investment = Investment Multiplier
formulas.explanation: Measures how much national income increases for each unit of public sector investment.

formulas.title: Private Sector Share in GDP
formulas.formula: (Private Sector GVA / Total GVA) × 100 = Private Sector Share %
formulas.explanation: Calculates the percentage contribution of the private sector to the total economy.

realworld.title: Disinvestment of PSUs
realworld.description: The government's policy of disinvestment in public sector undertakings (PSUs) like Air India reflects the changing role of the public sector in the economy.

realworld.title: Public-Private Partnership (PPP) Model
realworld.description: PPPs in infrastructure projects like highways and airports combine public sector oversight with private sector efficiency for better service delivery.

topics.name: Money as a Medium of Exchange

notes.title: Barter System and its Limitations
points: Barter system is the exchange of goods for goods without the use of money.
Limitations: Need for double coincidence of wants, lack of common measure of value, difficulty in storing wealth, and indivisibility of certain goods.
Example: A farmer with wheat who needs clothes must find a weaver who wants wheat in exchange for clothes.
The system becomes complex as the number of goods and services increases.

notes.title: Functions of Money
points: Medium of Exchange: Eliminates the need for double coincidence of wants.
Measure of Value: Provides a common measure for the value of goods and services.
Store of Value: Can be stored for future use without losing its value.
Standard of Deferred Payment: Enables transactions over time through credit.

formulas.title: Velocity of Money
formulas.formula: Nominal GDP / Money Supply = Velocity of Money
formulas.explanation: Measures how many times a unit of money changes hands in a given time period.

formulas.title: Quantity Theory of Money
formulas.formula: M × V = P × T
formulas.explanation: M = Money Supply, V = Velocity, P = Price Level, T = Volume of Transactions. Shows the relationship between money supply and price levels.

realworld.title: Demonetization in India (2016)
realworld.description: The Indian government's decision to demonetize ₹500 and ₹1000 currency notes aimed to curb black money and promote digital transactions, significantly impacting the cash-dependent economy.

realworld.title: Cryptocurrencies
realworld.description: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies challenge traditional money by providing a decentralized digital medium of exchange, though they face regulatory challenges.

notes.title: Currency and Bank Deposits
points: Currency: Includes paper notes and coins issued by the central bank (RBI in India).
Bank Deposits: Money deposited in bank accounts that can be withdrawn on demand (savings, current accounts).
Demand deposits are considered money as they can be used for making payments via cheques or digital means.
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has the sole authority to issue currency notes in India.

notes.title: Digital and Electronic Money
points: Plastic Money: Credit and debit cards that allow cashless transactions.
Mobile Wallets: Paytm, PhonePe, Google Pay, etc., for digital payments.
UPI (Unified Payments Interface): Real-time payment system developed by NPCI.
Internet Banking: Online banking services for fund transfers and bill payments.

formulas.title: Money Multiplier
formulas.formula: 1 / Reserve Ratio = Money Multiplier
formulas.explanation: Shows how much the money supply increases with each unit of new deposits in the banking system.

formulas.title: Digital Payment Adoption Rate
formulas.formula: (Number of Digital Transactions / Total Number of Transactions) × 100 = Digital Payment Adoption %
formulas.explanation: Measures the percentage of transactions conducted through digital means.

realworld.title: UPI Revolution in India
realworld.description: India's UPI system has become a global benchmark for digital payments, processing over 11 billion transactions worth ₹17.4 trillion in October 2023 alone.

realworld.title: China's Digital Yuan
realworld.description: China's pilot of the digital yuan represents a government-backed digital currency, potentially transforming the future of money and payments.

notes.title: Bank as a Financial Intermediary
points: Banks accept deposits from people who have surplus money and lend to those who need funds.
They charge higher interest on loans than what they offer on deposits, the difference being their main source of income.
Banks keep only a small proportion (15% in India) of deposits as cash reserves, lending out the rest.
This is known as the fractional reserve banking system.

notes.title: Credit Creation by Banks
points: Banks create credit through the process of lending.
When a bank gives a loan, it creates a deposit in the borrower's account, thereby increasing the money supply.
The total amount of money that the banking system can create depends on the reserve ratio.
Example: With a 20% reserve ratio, ₹1000 deposit can potentially create ₹5000 in the banking system.

formulas.title: Credit Creation Formula
formulas.formula: Initial Deposit × (1 / Reserve Ratio) = Total Money Creation
formulas.explanation: Calculates the maximum amount of money that can be created by the banking system from an initial deposit.

formulas.title: Net Interest Margin (NIM)
formulas.formula: (Interest Earned - Interest Paid) / Average Earning Assets = NIM
formulas.explanation: Measures the difference between interest income generated by banks and the amount of interest paid to lenders, relative to the amount of their assets.

realworld.title: Subprime Mortgage Crisis (2008)
realworld.description: The global financial crisis was triggered by excessive and risky lending by banks, particularly in the US housing market, leading to widespread defaults and economic downturn.

realworld.title: Microfinance in India
realworld.description: Institutions like SKS Microfinance (now Bharat Financial Inclusion) provide small loans to the poor, particularly women, enabling them to start small businesses and improve their livelihoods.

topics.name: Terms of Credit and Self Help Groups (SHGs)

notes.title: Terms of Credit
points: Interest Rate: The percentage of the principal that the borrower must pay as interest.
Collateral: An asset that the borrower owns (like land, building, vehicles, etc.) which is used as a guarantee to a lender until the loan is repaid.
Documentation: The borrower is required to submit documents proving their identity, income, and employment details.
Mode of Repayment: The schedule and method by which the loan will be repaid.

notes.title: Self Help Groups (SHGs)
points: A self-help group consists of 15-20 members, usually from the same neighborhood, who meet and save regularly.
Members can take small loans from the group itself to meet their needs at a reasonable interest rate.
After a year or two, if the group is regular in savings, it becomes eligible for bank loans without collateral.
SHGs help borrowers overcome the problem of lack of collateral and create self-employment opportunities.

notes.title: Formal and Informal Credit
points: Formal Sector: Includes banks and cooperatives which charge lower interest rates and are supervised by the RBI.
Informal Sector: Includes moneylenders, traders, employers, relatives, and friends who charge much higher interest rates.
The formal sector meets only about half of the total credit needs of rural people in India.
Cheaper credit from formal sources is crucial for the country's development.

formulas.title: Debt-to-Income Ratio (DTI)
formulas.formula: Total Monthly Debt Payments / Gross Monthly Income × 100 = DTI %
formulas.explanation: Measures the percentage of a borrower's income that goes toward paying debts, used by lenders to assess creditworthiness.

formulas.title: SHG Loan Repayment Rate
formulas.formula: (Amount Repaid / Amount Due) × 100 = Repayment Rate %
formulas.explanation: Measures the percentage of loans repaid by SHG members, indicating the group's credit discipline.

realworld.title: Grameen Bank Model
realworld.description: Founded by Muhammad Yunus in Bangladesh, this model provides small loans to the poor without requiring collateral, demonstrating high repayment rates and significant social impact.

realworld.title: Kudumbashree in Kerala
realworld.description: One of the largest women-empowering projects in India, with over 4.5 million members, focusing on microfinance, entrepreneurship, and social empowerment.

realworld.title: MUDRA Yojana
realworld.description: The Pradhan Mantri MUDRA Yojana (PMMY) provides loans up to ₹10 lakh to non-corporate, non-farm small/micro enterprises, formalizing the informal credit sector.

notes.title: Multinational Corporations (MNCs)
points: MNCs are companies that own or control production in more than one nation, with headquarters in one country and operations in multiple countries.
Examples: Apple, Samsung, Toyota, and Reliance Industries.
MNCs set up production where they can get cheap labor and other resources, close to markets, and favorable government policies.
They bring investment, technology, and employment opportunities to host countries.

notes.title: How MNCs Operate
points: Set up production jointly with local companies, providing money, technology, and expertise.
Buy local companies to expand production (e.g., Ford bought Jaguar and Land Rover).
Place orders for production with small producers (e.g., garments, footwear, sports items).
Use their global network to sell products worldwide, often under their own brand names.

formulas.title: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) Growth
formulas.formula: (Current Year FDI - Previous Year FDI) / Previous Year FDI × 100 = FDI Growth %
formulas.explanation: Measures the annual growth rate of foreign direct investment in a country.

formulas.title: MNC Market Share
formulas.formula: (MNC's Revenue in a Market / Total Market Revenue) × 100 = Market Share %
formulas.explanation: Calculates the percentage of total sales in a market captured by an MNC.

realworld.title: Apple's Global Supply Chain
realworld.description: Apple designs products in California, sources components from multiple countries, assembles them in China, and sells worldwide, exemplifying global production.

realworld.title: Tesla's Gigafactory in India
realworld.description: Tesla's plans to set up a manufacturing plant in India demonstrate how MNCs expand to tap into growing markets and leverage local manufacturing advantages.

notes.title: Global Supply Chains
points: Production is divided into small parts and spread across countries based on cost advantages.
Example: A car company may design its products in Germany, manufacture components in China, assemble in Mexico, and sell globally.
This interlinking is facilitated by improvements in transportation and communication technologies.
It has led to increased competition, efficiency, and lower prices for consumers.

notes.title: Role of Information Technology
points: IT has revolutionized communication and information exchange across the globe.
Video conferencing, email, and instant messaging enable real-time coordination across time zones.
E-commerce platforms like Amazon and Alibaba connect producers and consumers worldwide.
Digital payment systems facilitate seamless international transactions.

formulas.title: Global Supply Chain Efficiency
formulas.formula: Total Output / Total Input = Supply Chain Efficiency
formulas.explanation: Measures how effectively inputs are converted into outputs in global production networks.

formulas.title: Trade Openness Index
formulas.formula: (Exports + Imports) / GDP × 100 = Trade Openness %
formulas.explanation: Measures the degree to which a country's economy is integrated into the global trading system.

realworld.title: Boeing 787 Dreamliner
realworld.description: Boeing's 787 is assembled in the US but has components manufactured in over 15 countries, showcasing complex global supply chains.

realworld.title: India's IT-BPM Sector
realworld.description: India's IT industry, with exports of $194 billion (2023), provides back-office and technical support to global companies 24/7, enabled by digital connectivity.

topics.name: Foreign Trade and Integration of Markets

notes.title: Impact of Foreign Trade
points: Foreign trade creates opportunities for producers to reach beyond domestic markets.
Producers can compete in export markets, leading to improved quality and lower prices.
Consumers get access to a wider variety of goods at competitive prices.
Example: Chinese toys in Indian markets and Indian textiles in US markets.

notes.title: Trade Barriers and Liberalization
points: Governments use trade barriers like taxes on imports (tariffs) to regulate foreign trade.
Removing these barriers is called liberalization, allowing businesses to make decisions freely.
The World Trade Organization (WTO) establishes rules for international trade and ensures compliance.
India has significantly reduced trade barriers since the economic reforms of 1991.

formulas.title: Balance of Trade
formulas.formula: Value of Exports - Value of Imports = Balance of Trade
formulas.explanation: Measures the difference between a country's exports and imports of goods and services.

formulas.title: Revealed Comparative Advantage (RCA)
formulas.formula: (Country's Export Share of a Product / World's Export Share of that Product) × 100 = RCA
formulas.explanation: Measures a country's comparative advantage in specific products based on trade patterns.

realworld.title: India's Pharmaceutical Exports
realworld.description: India is the world's largest provider of generic medicines, meeting over 50% of global demand for various vaccines and supplying affordable medicines to developing countries.

realworld.title: US-China Trade War
realworld.description: The 2018-2020 trade war saw both countries imposing tariffs on billions of dollars worth of goods, disrupting global supply chains and affecting economies worldwide.

notes.title: Positive Impacts
points: Increased foreign investment and technology transfer, especially in IT, telecommunications, and automobiles.
Creation of new jobs, particularly in the service sector (call centers, BPOs, software companies).
Access to global markets for Indian companies (e.g., TCS, Infosys, Reliance).
Improved quality and reduced prices of goods and services due to competition.

notes.title: Negative Impacts
points: Small producers face tough competition from cheaper imports, sometimes leading to job losses.
Exploitation of workers in export processing zones with poor working conditions.
Environmental degradation due to increased industrial activity.
Widening income inequalities between skilled and unskilled workers.

notes.title: Government Initiatives
points: Make in India: To encourage domestic manufacturing and attract foreign investment.
Atmanirbhar Bharat: For self-reliance and reducing import dependence.
Production Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme: To boost domestic manufacturing and exports.
Special Economic Zones (SEZs): To promote exports and attract FDI with tax benefits.

formulas.title: Globalization Index
formulas.formula: (Economic Integration + Social Integration + Political Integration) / 3 = Globalization Score
formulas.explanation: Measures a country's level of integration into the global economy across multiple dimensions.

formulas.title: Employment Elasticity to GDP
formulas.formula: % Change in Employment / % Change in GDP = Employment Elasticity
formulas.explanation: Measures how employment changes with economic growth, indicating job creation effectiveness.

realworld.title: Indian IT Industry Growth
realworld.description: India's IT sector grew from $150 million in 1991 to over $245 billion in 2023, becoming a global hub for software services and creating millions of jobs.

realworld.title: Farmers' Protests 2020-21
realworld.description: Indian farmers protested against farm laws they feared would lead to corporate takeover of agriculture, highlighting tensions between global market forces and local agricultural communities.

realworld.title: India's Renewable Energy Push
realworld.description: India's ambitious target of 500 GW renewable energy capacity by 2030 demonstrates how globalization can drive sustainable development through technology transfer and international cooperation.

topics.name: Why do we need Political Parties?

notes.title: Functions of Political Parties
points: Contesting Elections: Parties put up candidates to contest elections and form the government.
Making Policies: They formulate policies and programs for the welfare of the people.
Law Making: Parties play a decisive role in making laws for the country.
Formation of Government: The party with majority forms the government and runs the administration.
Role of Opposition: Parties that lose elections play the role of opposition by criticizing the government.

notes.title: Necessity of Political Parties
points: They provide a platform for citizens to participate in the political process.
Parties bring various representatives together to form a responsible government.
They help in the formation of public opinion on various issues.
Parties provide access to government machinery and welfare schemes.
They ensure that the country runs as per set policies and ideologies.

formulas.title: Party System Effectiveness Index
formulas.formula: Representation + Accountability + Policy Formulation + Public Participation = Effectiveness Score
formulas.explanation: Measures how effectively a party system represents citizens' interests and contributes to governance.

formulas.title: Voter-Party Alignment
formulas.formula: Number of Aligned Voters / Total Voters × 100 = Alignment %
formulas.explanation: Measures the percentage of voters whose views align with a party's ideology and policies.

realworld.title: Role of BJP and Congress in Indian Democracy
realworld.description: BJP (Bharatiya Janata Party) and Indian National Congress, as major national parties, have played crucial roles in shaping India's policies, governance, and political discourse since independence.

realworld.title: Aam Aadmi Party's Emergence
realworld.description: The formation of AAP in 2012 and its subsequent electoral success in Delhi demonstrated how new parties can emerge to address perceived gaps in political representation.

topics.name: How many Parties should we have?

notes.title: Types of Party Systems
points: One-Party System: Only one party is allowed to control and run the government (e.g., China).
Two-Party System: Power alternates between two major parties (e.g., USA with Democrats and Republicans).
Multi-Party System: Several parties compete for power, and government is formed through coalition (e.g., India).
India follows a multi-party system where various national and regional parties contest elections.

notes.title: Advantages of Multi-Party System
points: Provides a variety of choices to voters.
Ensures representation of diverse groups and regions.
Prevents monopoly of a single party.
More responsive to people's demands due to competition.
Reflects the social and geographical diversity of India.

formulas.title: Effective Number of Parties
formulas.formula: 1 / (Sum of Squares of Each Party's Vote Share) = ENP
formulas.explanation: Measures the number of 'effective' parties in a political system, considering both the number and relative strength of parties.

formulas.title: Party System Fragmentation Index
formulas.formula: 1 - (Sum of Squares of Parties' Seat Shares) = Fragmentation Index
formulas.explanation: Measures the degree of fragmentation in a party system, ranging from 0 (one-party dominance) to 1 (complete fragmentation).

realworld.title: Coalition Governments in India
realworld.description: The era of coalition governments (1996-2014) showed how multiple parties with different ideologies can come together to form stable governments at the center.

realworld.title: Rise of Regional Parties
realworld.description: Parties like DMK in Tamil Nadu, TMC in West Bengal, and BJD in Odisha highlight how regional parties represent state-specific interests in India's federal structure.

notes.title: National Parties
points: A party that secures at least 6% of the total votes in Lok Sabha or Assembly elections in four or more states and wins at least 4 seats in the Lok Sabha.
As of 2023, there are 8 national parties in India: BJP, INC, CPI(M), CPI, BSP, NPP, AAP, and NCP.
They have a presence across several states and influence national politics.
Examples: BJP (Bharatiya Janata Party), INC (Indian National Congress).

notes.title: State Parties
points: A party that secures at least 6% of the total votes in an Assembly or Lok Sabha election in a state and wins at least 2 seats in the Assembly.
They operate within a particular state and their influence is limited to that state.
Examples: DMK and AIADMK in Tamil Nadu, TMC in West Bengal, BJD in Odisha.
They play a crucial role in forming state governments and influencing national politics through coalitions.

formulas.title: Party Nationalization Score
formulas.formula: 1 - (Standard Deviation of Party's Vote Share Across States / 0.5)
formulas.explanation: Measures how nationally distributed a party's support is, ranging from 0 (completely regional) to 1 (completely national).

formulas.title: Party System Nationalization
formulas.formula: 1 - (Average of Squared Differences Between National and State Vote Shares)
formulas.explanation: Measures how similar party systems are across different states in a country.

realworld.title: BJP's Expansion Strategy
realworld.description: BJP's expansion from being a party with limited presence in 1984 (2 seats) to forming a full majority government in 2014 and 2019 demonstrates how national parties can expand their base.

realworld.title: Regional Parties in Coalition Politics
realworld.description: The role of parties like DMK, TDP, and Shiv Sena in national coalition governments (like UPA and NDA) shows how state parties can influence national policies.

notes.title: Major Challenges
points: Lack of Internal Democracy: Concentration of power in a few leaders at the top.
Dynastic Succession: Leadership passing from one family member to another.
Money and Muscle Power: Increasing role of money and muscle power in elections.
Lack of Meaningful Choice: Parties becoming similar in policies and practices.
Corruption and Criminalization: Growing criminalization of politics and corruption in political funding.

notes.title: Reforms to Strengthen Parties
points: Law to regulate internal affairs of political parties.
Quota for women candidates in party tickets.
State funding of elections to reduce money power.
Decentralization of power within parties.
Transparent funding through electoral bonds and digital payments.

notes.title: Recent Reforms in India
points: Electoral Bonds for transparent political funding (introduced in 2017).
Ceiling on election expenditure by candidates.
Mandatory disclosure of criminal records by candidates.
Introduction of NOTA (None of the Above) option in EVMs.
Supreme Court's directives on decriminalization of politics.

formulas.title: Party System Institutionalization Index
formulas.formula: Stability + Legitimacy + Autonomy = Institutionalization Score
formulas.explanation: Measures how established and stable a country's party system is across different dimensions.

formulas.title: Women's Representation Index
formulas.formula: Number of Women Candidates / Total Candidates × 100 = Women's Representation %
formulas.explanation: Measures the percentage of women candidates fielded by political parties.

realworld.title: Anti-Defection Law
realworld.description: The 52nd Amendment Act (1985) introduced the anti-defection law to prevent elected representatives from switching parties, though its implementation has faced challenges.

realworld.title: Electoral Bond Scheme
realworld.description: Introduced in 2017, electoral bonds aimed to bring transparency in political funding, though they have been controversial regarding donor anonymity.

realworld.title: Supreme Court's Verdict on Criminalization
realworld.description: The Supreme Court's 2013 ruling that convicted lawmakers would be immediately disqualified was a significant step against criminalization of politics.

notes.title: Accountability in Democracy
points: Democracy ensures that the government is accountable to the people through regular, free, and fair elections.
Citizens have the right to question and scrutinize government decisions and actions.
Mechanisms like Question Hour, debates, and discussions in the legislature ensure transparency.
Right to Information (RTI) Act empowers citizens to seek information from public authorities.

notes.title: Responsiveness and Legitimacy
points: Democratic governments are expected to be responsive to the needs and expectations of the people.
They are more likely to be attentive to the demands of the majority while protecting minority rights.
Legitimacy comes from the fact that democratic governments are elected by the people.
Democracy's ability to handle social differences and conflicts enhances its legitimacy.

formulas.title: Government Responsiveness Index
formulas.formula: (Policy Changes + Public Grievance Redressal + Public Opinion Implementation) / 3 = Responsiveness Score
formulas.explanation: Measures how responsive a government is to public needs and demands.

formulas.title: Legitimacy Quotient
formulas.formula: Voter Turnout × Public Trust in Institutions × Rule of Law Index = Legitimacy Score
formulas.explanation: Quantifies the perceived legitimacy of a democratic government.

realworld.title: Right to Information Act (2005)
realworld.description: The RTI Act has empowered Indian citizens to seek information from public authorities, making the government more accountable and transparent in its functioning.

realworld.title: Social Audit in MGNREGA
realworld.description: The social audit mechanism under MGNREGA allows citizens to monitor and evaluate government programs, ensuring better implementation and reducing corruption.

notes.title: Democracy and Economic Growth
points: Democracies don't always show higher economic growth rates compared to dictatorships.
However, they provide a more stable political environment for long-term economic development.
Democracies are better at preventing famines and ensuring food security (e.g., India's success in preventing famines since independence).
They ensure that economic benefits are more evenly distributed across different sections of society.

notes.title: Quality of Decision Making
points: Democratic decisions are more acceptable to the people as they involve consultation and discussion.
Decisions are likely to be more effective as they are based on deliberation and negotiation.
Democracies take time to arrive at decisions but implement them more effectively due to public support.
Example: Economic reforms of 1991 in India were implemented through democratic consensus.

formulas.title: Human Development Index (HDI)
formulas.formula: (Life Expectancy Index + Education Index + GNI per capita Index) / 3 = HDI
formulas.explanation: A composite index measuring average achievement in three basic dimensions of human development.

formulas.title: Economic Inequality Index
formulas.formula: 1 - Gini Coefficient = Equality Score
formulas.explanation: Measures income distribution where 0 represents perfect equality and 1 represents perfect inequality.

realworld.title: Kerala's Development Model
realworld.description: Kerala's high human development indicators despite modest per capita income demonstrate how democratic governance can prioritize social welfare and human development.

realworld.title: China vs. India Growth Story
realworld.description: While China achieved rapid economic growth under an authoritarian regime, India's democratic system ensured more inclusive growth and better protection of civil liberties.

notes.title: Addressing Economic Inequalities
points: Democracies are expected to reduce economic disparities through progressive taxation and welfare measures.
They implement policies for poverty alleviation (e.g., MGNREGA, PM-KISAN, Ayushman Bharat).
Reservation policies for SCs, STs, and OBCs aim to reduce social and economic inequalities.
Democracies tend to have lower income inequality compared to non-democracies over time.

notes.title: Social Welfare and Redistribution
points: Democratic governments implement social security schemes for the underprivileged.
Public distribution system (PDS) ensures food security for the poor.
Education and healthcare are made accessible to all sections of society.
Example: Mid-day meal scheme has improved school enrollment and nutrition levels.

formulas.title: Poverty Gap Index
formulas.formula: Σ [(Poverty Line - Income of Poor) / Poverty Line] / Total Population
formulas.explanation: Measures the intensity of poverty by considering how far the poor are from the poverty line.

formulas.title: Social Mobility Index
formulas.formula: (Education Mobility + Income Mobility + Occupational Mobility) / 3 = Mobility Score
formulas.explanation: Measures the ability of individuals to move up the social and economic ladder.

realworld.title: Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT)
realworld.description: DBT has reduced leakages in welfare schemes by directly transferring benefits to beneficiaries' bank accounts, ensuring better targeting and reduced corruption.

realworld.title: Self-Help Group Movement
realworld.description: SHGs have empowered millions of rural women economically, demonstrating how democratic decentralization can reduce poverty and gender inequality.

topics.name: Dignity and Freedom of the Citizens

notes.title: Fundamental Rights and Freedoms
points: Democracy ensures fundamental rights like freedom of speech, expression, and religion.
Right to equality and prohibition of discrimination (Articles 14-18).
Right to constitutional remedies (Article 32) allows citizens to approach courts for violation of rights.
Freedom of press and media ensures transparency and accountability.

notes.title: Dignity of Individuals
points: Democracy enhances the dignity of individuals by recognizing the principle of political equality.
It provides equal status and opportunity to all citizens regardless of caste, religion, or gender.
Example: Abolition of untouchability and prohibition of discrimination (Article 17).
Women's empowerment through political participation and legal rights.

notes.title: Accommodation of Social Diversity
points: Democracy develops mechanisms for negotiation and deliberation to manage social diversity.
It provides methods to resolve conflicts in a peaceful manner.
Example: Linguistic reorganization of states in India accommodated regional aspirations.
Protection of minority rights ensures that democracy does not become rule by majority.

formulas.title: Freedom Index
formulas.formula: (Political Rights + Civil Liberties + Rule of Law) / 3 = Freedom Score
formulas.explanation: Measures the degree of political rights and civil liberties in a country.

formulas.title: Social Inclusion Index
formulas.formula: (Gender Equality + Minority Rights + Social Protection) / 3 = Inclusion Score
formulas.explanation: Measures how inclusive a society is across different social groups.

realworld.title: Right to Education Act (2009)
realworld.description: The RTE Act made education a fundamental right for children aged 6-14, demonstrating democracy's commitment to individual dignity through education.

realworld.title: Decriminalization of Section 377
realworld.description: The Supreme Court's 2018 verdict decriminalizing homosexuality marked a significant step in recognizing the dignity and rights of the LGBTQ+ community in India.

realworld.title: Panchayati Raj System
realworld.description: The 73rd and 74th Constitutional Amendments empowered local self-governments, ensuring greater participation of marginalized sections, including women and SC/STs, in democratic governance.
